reviewText:
First off ultimate opinion.

Do not spend ANY money on this game, not one cent.
However. the game is free to play, so there is no harm in playing.

Now for the why.
#1: Development is stalled, as far as I can tell it's been months if not a year since any developer involvment.
#2: The game currently suffers from a massive bug that wipes your storyline progress and so basically locks you out of endgame content that is unlocked via the storyline.
#3: No real future for this game, It's broken, and unloved by the developers who created it, honestly it is a fun game to play, but the endless list of bug and issues take to much away to make it a option for a fun weekend.

reviewText: I have no idea what all these negative reviews are... It's a single player game, how the hell is it pay to win? Yea, you see other players and they can send monsters into your realm, but it's not hard to beat them. And when you go up against a player, it's the computer that you're regularly fighting, just with an actual persons character. Don't listen to the haters, this game is not P2W.\n\nIt's a great mix of Demons Souls and God Of War. You can see ghosts of other players and you can choose to help them or curse them, both benefiting you in some ways. The combat system is very much like god of war, tons of gore, there really are only heavy weapon moves and light weapon moves no matter what actual weapon type you're using, but there are a handful of combos and you definitely need to be dodging and blocking on the harder bosses and the AI controlled players. Overall a good game, and I have yet to spend a dime on it and I'm doing just fine, don't hate the game, hate all the players.

reviewText:
This Game is beyond Pay2Win, In 40minutes it manages to become Pay2Play as your gear breaks pretty fast.
And it matters little if it is lowest or top grade gear.
There is forge which you can use to repair gear, does not take long, but it only repairs currently equipped gear.
It can repair your gear while you are offline.

Having 2 or 3 sets of equipment does not help to prolong play time too, since you have to repair each set after another basically keeping play to down time ratio same.

If your weapon breaks you have God's dagger which deals 1 DMG per hit and spells with incredibly high recharge which are capable to kill lowest creeps in 2 casts (dmg upgraded to max).
Each spell can be upgraded to improve damage, recharge rate and for some number of stored uses.

reviewText:
The game itself is great.  Darksouls and maybe a few other action RPG type games play heavy influence.  You are usually alone but you can often see other players in their own worlds and can interact with them indirectly, like sending monsters into their realm or if they are on your side, sending a buff to their stats or other gift.  Combat is rewarding and requires a bit of skill which translates to you being able to technically take on better equiped opponents with skill and clever manipulation of the enviroment.  You can even gather villagers who will climb onto you and fight with you.  It gives you some interesting ways to play and win though the enemies you face will often be tough opponents and fight well.

The problem is that you need to rely on a server which fails frequently.  You will often lose progress and the game sometimes loads information from the server wrong and freezes up.  The devs seem to be either procrastinating or just gone.  I don't know what happened but it apparently seems that they have all but abandoned the game, and even that may not be far off.

The game is dying and everyone is angry about it but there is ultimately nothing we can really do if the devs have lost their will to work on it.  Stay away to save yourself heartbreak.

reviewText:
Alot of negative feedback for no reason.

I easily have over 100 hours on my xbox account and for a free-to-play game, it is a ton of fun.  You spawn in as a giant demi-god surrounded by humans worshipping you.  Damn straight!  Off to a good start I'd say.

Game has three gods in which to serve and serving each grants you access to different dungeons and powers.  Plus you have the option to switch every 5 levels!  Once you hit max level... you start again, getting to choose what items/powers you want to carry over into your new life.  Bam rinse repeat.  Great time burner and easy to play, with a fun combat system with combos and spells.  Big monsters... even some you will literally have to climb up.

Multi-player aspect?  Near non-existant.  You are able to see other players, but they appear as ghosts and you cannot directly interact with them.  Doesn't mean you can't jack them up and kill them!  You can banish your enemies straight to them, or simply create a spawner in their 'world' and watch your creatures go hard.  You can also help others out with blessings.  But what's the fun in that...

For those of you (and yes.. there are so many of you)  who whine and complain about this being a money scam and how you have to pay-to-play..  Just do us all a favor and Stfu.  Learn how to play games.  The option to buy stuff will always be there in free games.  They got bills to pay too!  And players without any skill will feel it is necessary to spend real money to advance.  Believe me... I have never felt the need the pay to keep my ♥♥♥♥ going.  And trust me, I know there are games like that for real.. and this is not one of them.

So ya.. there is an honest review.  You will find this game to give you many hours of fun :)
voteText: 104 of 138 people (75%) found this review helpful 18 people found this review funny

reviewText:
With the exception of some minor technical gripes, and connection issues (so far), Ascend is a solid hack and slash RPG. You control a titan that you can customize (a few faces here and there, some of it is microtransactions), choose a following, between Dark, Light and Void. You can take over a village and have a bunch of dudes on your back as followers, and you can throw said dudes wherever you want. As for the multiplayer aspect, though it is light in implementation, favouring a more asynchronous approach. You can send curses and blessings to other players, there is leaderboards, etc.
This is one of the few free-to-play games that doesn't forcefeed microtransactions down your throat, despite them being quite fair and broad. You can buy souls for real world money (you start off with 3000 initially), or you can grind your way through the game to earn them.

Keep in mind that this game requires an internet connection at all times due to the asynch multiplayer, leaderboards and game data.
But for a free game that was also free on Xbox 360, it's an impressive game so far.

reviewText:
This will be lengthy and a little in depth, you will also most likely save yourself the time of downloading it/installing it/playing it/uninstalling it.

To quickly generalize the game, it is much like God of War: Ascension(more so the multiplayer portion is what I was reminded of in the sense that each weapon has its own set of combo moves albeit slightly limiting when compared to singleplayer game, you also pick an alignment/god that defines your set of spells) and with a little Dark Souls mixed in(kill things for souls, spend them to upgrade, some boss fights are lengthy and there is some emphasis on blocking and dodging attacks, invading other player's worlds).

Has a lot of pay to win elements to it. Sure everything can be bought with currency you earn from playing but the prices are often times set so high, that there is no realistic way to buy them other than with your wallet or by investing a lot of time. Chances are if you go the route of investing your time instead, you will have leveled up plenty and be shown other, better items, that are also priced very high.

It may also be worth mentioning that this was previously a console game and the menus really reflect this. Often times navigating through the menus just doesn't make sense on a keyboard and mouse or the buttons for you to click on are misaligned, because of this I bought upgrades I didn't intend to buy and sold a lot of items I meant to equip instead. The way the map functioned was also frustrating, if I was using a controller it would have made sense (to try and clarify a bit, instead of just putting your mouse over an icon on the map that you have interest in, you instead have to grab the entire map and shift everything until the icon you are insterested in, is in the center of the screen, WHY!?!).

Some elements of the game could have also been explained a lot more clearly, for example ascending. I still have plenty of questions on how it works but the game explained almost nothing about this apprently important aspect of the game. I instead had to look up wiki's and guides on it, only to discover I should have ascended at level 5 and if I ascended any later I would be missing out on some perks in the late game (you get a passive each time you ascend but cannot ascend once you are at level cap). I was already past level 5 at the time since the game gave no indication that it's better to do this sooner. Now on to explain what ascending is since the game does very little to explain this. If you ascend, the game more or less takes a snapshot of everything that makes up your character such as gears/spells/etc. and turns it into a npc that invades other players worlds, which can earn you a tiny amount of in game currency if successful (it wont be, as it will die a lot, unless of course you ascended with really powerful gear, aka used your wallet). Cool concept until you realize how much the game wants you to spend money at this point, ascending destroys your character and you make a new one(from what I can tell your new character starts 5 levels back, not sure why you go back 5 levels other than to artificially extend the game?). Part of the ascension process allows you to keep 1 piece of gear, so naturally you hold on to your best piece, every character going forward will have access to this item, of course you can preserve more items by paying to keep each one. Also part of new character creation process involves showing you all the powerful items you could buy instead! So to summarize ascending is destroying your character to in turn rollback 5 or so levels, lose your gear unless you choose to pay to save it or pay and buy new gear which you will then want to pay to save on your next ascension.

Shortly after my first ascension I had started one of the tougher boss fights (boss had a life pool that would have taken a couple hundred hits to kill, less if I bought nice gear though!). The boss felt glitchy all across the board. I initially fought it as intended, I would dodge and block when possible but the boss would frequently do quick 180's and hit me instantly, leaving little room to react. Challenge is nice if it feels fair, but having the constant thought in the back of my head that this challenge would not exist if I had chosen pay to win options is not fun, then add on top of that that the fight is buggy. Eventually I discovered a set of stairs on the edge of the designated fight area where I could freely cast spells and the boss would just sit and stare at me while he slowly died. Rather than spend 20 minutes abusing a glitch to kill the boss I instead wrote this review. GG.

reviewText:
First off, I love this game. The combat is awesome, the customization is just endless, the armor and weapons look AWESOME. The idea of actually being a giant with humans devoted to you is brilliant. Why am I rating it negatively? Pay to win. At the beginning it prolonged it by giving you 50k souls to spend (which you waste half of at the beginning) so you wouldn't need souls. But when you get low on souls, everything turns to ♥♥♥♥. Let's put it like this, if you were to continuously fight a single mob over and over and over again, you would lose souls. Why? They damage your armor extrememly fast, so it makes you repair every half an hour or so. Repairing costs near 10k souls for some armor/ weapons, and each mob gives you about 5 souls. Eventually everything of yours will be broken and you will have no souls left, making you pay to get more so you can repeat the process. Anyone who says it's not P2W is just kidding themselves.

The mobs are also extremely easy (the witch doctors are just annoying). They die in a couple of hits, but then suddenly you are pitted against ogres, which take off a quarter of your health in a couple swings and knock you down so you can't do anything while they are demolishing you. They also have super high health. To actually fight them you need better items, which means more money spent for souls!

I would pay money for this game if they were to just get rid of this P2W ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.

reviewText:
My review:

First:
Ok, so with everyone talking about the bug??? i have not yet encountered it


Good:

- free to play
- Be a giant and go on a rampage of terror for your chosen god!
- Sacrifice priests at alters to claim them for your god!
- have humans ride you as you stomp through the wilderness (they will protect you by launching firey arrows at your enimes... you can also eat a few to regain health)
- Partially destructable environment!!!
- level and *ASCEND* (Ascending means at certain levels you can kill your *CHAMPION* and re-birth him to make him EVEN STRONGER!
- invade players worlds by giving them boons or curses!!!
- Dungeons (single player of course)
- fight another players avatar to take control of his *realm*
- everyone starts the game with FIFTY THOUSAND SOULS to spend!!!!
- replayability
- various chests hidden around the world which contain armor/weapons/boons and curses

Bad:

- Developement appears to have stopped on this game (it was always funky to begin with anyway - i had this on the 360)
-SEMI-Multy player (imagine a single player game, where you can AFFECT another person INDIRECTLY lol)
- some people are complaining about a *game killing* bug, where your story progress will be reset (you still keep all your currently gathered souls/weapons and armour - I have YET to experience this bug)
- too short in my opinion AND VERY LINEAR (this comment comes from playing the original on the 360... and it appears unchanged at the moment)

NOTE: some people claim this game is pay to win... it is NOT... with the 50k souls at the start you can buy almost everything you will EVER need (and every kill you will earn MORE souls... the ammount depending on how fast/stylish those kills are (times by your combo ammount i.e combo 20 = 2x iirc )

NOTE II: This game is FREE TO PLAY... you have nothing to lose (well... appart from your social life if you enjoy this)

NOTE III: The game says it only has PARTIAL controller support... this is a LIE... it has FULL controller support (360)

What have you got to lose?

reviewText: An interesting game that has an unusual flare, ASCEND is a game that I would cetainly recommend. The main complaint that most people have about this game is that it is 'pay2play'. This is complete rubbish; I have racked up a fair few hours and have not paid a penny. If your weapons/ armour break you can repair them instantly for a small fee, repair them for free over a few hours (as long as they are not completely broken) or just find some new stuff in chests. Simple money managemwnt is important, so those people who don't plan ahead will fail in the first 45 minutes, but simple perseverance can restore you. When my weapon first broke, I just fought with a weaker starter blade, which was challenging, but got me enough sould to repair my other weapon. It isn't that hard. Combat is entertaining, although the enemies can become repetetive, and a simple loot system makes dungeon crawling rewarding. The peculiar player vs player action is enjoyable, although occasionally irritating- particularly when idiots on your own team attack you- and gives ASCEND a unique twist. A thoroughly enjoyable game of a unique style with good action and a respectable storyline, ASCEND is a great game from a  smally company that I would certainly recommend. Besides, it's free, so what is there to lose?

reviewText: Considering the fact that most free to play games are MMO's or Arena Shooters and are usually synonymous with being udder crap, I was actually kind of suprised when I played this game. It's just a Beat-em up / Hack 'n' Slash sudo RPG where you play as a giant 'Caos' that must appease his chosen god via sacrifice. You run around hitting creatures with a big stick, and occasionally hit other players with a big stick, gain control over human territory, they worship you, and then you eat them. The gameplay isn't very deep, but it all fits together coherently into a playable and somewhat fun game, and you don't have to play diddly squat for it.\n\nIt's defiantely worth giving a try because by no means is it a bad game, as it's paywall and repeative gameplay are it's only negative faults. A pleasent surprise from Steam's usually crap these days.

reviewText: In general, this game is good. The fact that you can serve the god of your choice is awesome, I've never seen it in a game before. The controls and everything else are fine but I have one problem that holds the game back  from being a brilliant game. For the first couple of hours, the game is a good bit of fun, killing things, getting new items and other things, but the fun stops when you get to the first proper boss fight. The boss is way too overpowered and I feel that you need to pay money to get good enough items to defeat the boss. The thing that got me the most was the fact that when you finally kill the boss after about 30 minutes of fighting, the boss regenerates about two thirds of its health and you feel as if you're back where you started. I know the game is in beta and I know this may be an issue they may fix, but if they're going to make a game pay to win, then it's a waste of most people's time who just want to have a little bit of fun with it.

reviewText:
This game takes the super low weapon durability of Dead Island and turns it into a f2p cash cow, combining it with a clunky combat system and the dull, uninteresting art from Darksiders to make one mess of a game.  It does have a few interesting ideas with player interaction and the different gods, but they take a pretty far back seat to the flaws of the game.

All the equipment you find is heavily damaged and wears out quickly, requiring frequent repairs.  What little money you gain from playing is quickly sunk into equipment repairs if you want to use any piece for more than 10 minutes.  Never mind that you need to use that same currency to upgrade your spells.

Combat is slow and clunky, with only two simple attack moves, block, dash, and spells.  Every hit you take and many of the attacks you block will stagger you, yet enemies are only staggered at random and often can recover and attack you before you can land another attack.  Blocking seems to be instant so it doesn't have to wait for your previous action to finish, but it just leads to spamming block all the time which is pretty poor design if you ask me.  But hey, you can buy boosts to attack faster to make the combat easier!

This game looked interesting and I wanted to enjoy it, but it's just another f2p grind.  No thanks.

Before I get into this review let me tell you something... I really like this game, I played it before it came on Steam, and its an awseome game. Now before I end let me tell you some things about the game I recommend just be carefull you don't bump into the problem that I have... It has a good storyline unlike other RPG styled games which are impossible to keep up with, yes i'm looking at you Everquest and Dragon Nest, nice combat also and there are 3 factions in the game Good, Void and Evil. Its a great game ,it really is, i'm just annoyed that I cannot continue it and that is why I cannot recommend it in its current state. I hope that people understand I am not hating the gameplay and story itself just the servers.

reviewText:
So far so good, however, every game has pros and cons. This is true with this game as well. So far I have seen that there are numerous glitches/ bugs. Granted they are minor but they are still present.
Cons:
1. When I dash into a rock in a dugeon, it slings me into the air.
2. I chose the darkness path. if you use the fourth spell, meteor storm, it will make the enemy chaos stand there vunerable.
3. This could be a connection error, however, the game does kick me out of the server at random times. Not too often, but it still happens.
4.The game freezes at important times. These include: Ascending, beating an apex, getting a new power bestowed upon you. Once again not frequent, but kind of annoying.
Pros:
1. For a free game, it is not too bad of a pay to win. As long as you are smart with your money (souls).
2. It may be repetative, but the game keeps throwing slight curveballs at you. Such as the bridge scene going to the second apex, or randomly dropping new semi-bosses on you.
3. The combo system is pretty good, however when you use a spell like fireball it does not always count as a hit.
4. I love how you can choose a new god to follow after everytime you ascend. Instead of being bound to just one throught the ENTIRE game, like I can't even choose between salad or soup at a restraunt.

Overall it is a pretty fun/great game, which I enjoy. There is always room for improvement in any game, however producers, artists, and programmars are only human. They can't please everyone. So have a nice day everyone.

reviewText:
Currently, it is the best there is in the '' free to play '' Steam, it is that, a free to play, don't need to pay for nothing, because if you have little free time, you earn money as each ascension, you are granted a bot that is as if it were you before ascending the what helps you collect souls (I currently have 3, I have 100 domain zones and every two days have 40,000 souls collected), if there are any interesting weapon do not have enough souls NO PROBLEM, shop filled every so often, about 25mins to 1 hour, at that time (you should go somewhat advanced) get those souls who want to spend much.
Pros:
+ good graphics
+ A bit difficult (in terms of PVP, PvE and becomes more difficult when you invade)
+ short main history, but infinite after.
+ spells are very useful in combat, unlike other games
Cons:
-it badly balanced, you'll be level 44, yes, but you find another who may have transcended 2 times, and having an armor of the ♥♥♥♥ing hell, either hack, developer, or whatever, but it costs.
-the runes do not add a lot, had 2 in a weapon and I just did not add bonus damage, with speed equal.
-even having a good graphics, is poorly optimized, it's going very lagged playing with all the minimum settings, but you can play.
-And occasionally, the character does '' superjumps '' and that you can not even give them normal, they send you to all you can not go out and ♥♥♥♥ you live making restart the map, taking back to as ♥♥♥♥ing enemy who took 20 minutes to kill.

To be f2p, it deserves a 9/10
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Actualmente,es de lo mejor que hay en el apartado ''free to play'' de Steam,pues es eso,un free to play,no hay que pagar por NADA,pues si tienes poco tiempo libre,ganarás dinero ya que por cada ascensión,te conceden un bot que es como si fueras tú antes de ascender,el cuál te ayuda a recolectar almas(yo actualmente tengo 3,tengo 100 zonas de dominio y cada dos días tengo 40.000 almas recogidas),si hay algún arma interesante y no tienes suficientes almas NO HAY PROBLEMA,la tienda se rellena cada cierto tiempo,aproximadamente 25mins a 1 hora,en ese tiempo(hay que ir algo avanzado)conseguirás esas almas que tanto quieres gastar.
Pros:
+buena gráfica
+algo difícil(en cuanto al PVP,el PvE ya se torna más difícil cuando te invaden)

Contras:
-está mal balanceado,puedes ser nivel 44,sí,pero te encuentras con otro que puede haber trascendido 2 veces,y que tenga una armadura de la hostia,ya sea hack,programador,o lo que sea,pero cuesta.
-las runas no aportan demasiado,tenía 2 en un arma y no me añadía apenas bonificación de daño,con la velocidad,igual.
-aún teniendo una buena gráfica,está mal optimizado,me va muy lageado jugando con todo al mínimo,pero se puede jugar.
-de vez en cuando,el personaje da ''supersaltos'',y eso que no puedes ni darlos normales,que te envían a zonas de las que no puedes salir y te joden vivo haciendo que reinices el mapa,teniendo de nuevo al tan jodido enemigo que te costó 20 minutos matar.

Para ser f2p,se merece un 9/10

reviewText: The game starts out fairly promising. For a F2P, it looks pretty decent and runs smoothly. The tutorial is straight forward, and the gameplay is interesting enough to make you play through the 30 minute introduction. And then the real game starts. If you enjoy hitting two buttons continously for hours on end, this game will be for you because thats how complex the combat is. Light Attack and Heavy Attack. I endured it for about an hour and a half, until I was invaded for the first time. My invader, at a level lower than I, hit me with a spell that immediately took half of my HP. A spell only available to me if I had paid money to earn more souls. Only an idiot would throw any money at this game, but considering it probably only took about 10 dollars to develop, I imagine it only takes one idiot for the developers to make any profit. TL;DR, repetivie combat, no enemy originality, pay to win. NOT FUN

reviewText: Let me be the first to say that this game is most certainly not perfect; by any means whatsoever- and yet I've played it for this long, beat it, ate a few humans, and essentially became a juggernaut of titanic proportions. This game just... feels good; I can't NOT recommend it. It's a strange kind of fun that you just have to try out; mind you I am aware that this game is not for everyone. While it does have a story (and one that isn't half bad) its main aspect is killing, viciously and mercilessly tearing your enemies piece by piece with whatever fancy weapon you have equipped. Most of the game is spent doing that; and the time you're not spending killing, you're getting to places where you will be killing. If you can forgive its simplistic AI, its occasional bugs and the strangeness of how it decides to do things. You'll find a pretty swell game, that's worth a few hours of your time and without any risk involved but a short download.\n\nDespite the game's fair option of paying your way through its currency, you can receive the currency just as well as being skilled enough in the game to keep your combos going and learning which way is best to deal with your foes. I've not spent a  dime on this game and I came out with a supremely powerful weapon, great armour and the knowledge of how to deal with my enemies without them even laying a finger on me. If you've got some time to spare, give this game a whirl.

reviewText: This game was brilliant to start with especially since its in beta stage, using fun hack and slash gameplay mixed ith a reward system that is touchy yet can be rewarding, the main problem is after your second ascension it gets difficult, like REALLY difficult, dark souls difficult, the amount of souls you get in comparison to the price of upgrade/repair/new gear/spell cost, dungeon cost etc is incredibly low, to the point that you will be walking around barefoot with a wooden stick because you cant afford to repair or buy new equipment, the endgame of this is that you buy souls, okay yes souls are INCREDIBLY cheap but if you dont want to spend money on a game then you would be unable to progress, i played this untill i was no longer unable to progress, not due to skill but to lack of equipment that functions, if i was the developer i would either increase the drop of souls by 3 or 4 times or remove the repair aspect of the game, because at this point after an hour or so of playing, the game is essentially broken with no room to progress

reviewText: YOU are a towering armor-clad giant carrying an army of devout followers to battle in hopes of securing the land for your god. You're going to devastate hordes of twisted monsters, splatter waves of enemy followers beneath your boot, and even go head-to-head against the champions of rival gods. You are also going to get stuck in a horrible pay-to-win cycle that rots the game to its very core.\n\nAmazing concept. Cool mechanics. Decent-enough graphics. Nice customization. HORRIBLE payment model. Please just charge for $15 and let me acctually enough your game, instead of always being starved of souls because of the constant gear repair and massive costs of any interesting items/abilities.

reviewText:
Okay where to begin...

Automatically, I must say, as a self-imposed rule as a gamer if you charge money for your game, claim to be an mmo and then don't make female playable characters you're automatically on my 'will never actually spend money on this' list, but this game is just so repetitive and so dull - you can't skip cutscenes and everything thats in here has been done before by God of War and the not-as-good-but-moderately entertaining Dante's Inferno - fight gods' little pathetic minions, convert ♥♥♥♥, be holy or evil blah blah blah.

The customization is surprisingly limited unless you begin really shelling out either the money or the time to farm - which is funny for a game that didn't bother to spend production money making female playable characters you'd think they would spend more time making more models for this stuff, at a more reasonable price. But oh well.

At first its kind of cool, the one unique thing about this game is that you can play a massive big-♥♥♥ giant and command humans to jump on you and fight, but even that is a basically depthless system. You can't 'bless' your human servants, you don't get particularly any stronger by bringing them with you either, it doesn't feel like your gaining any followers of your own like a 'demigod' as the storyline basically sets you up to be.

A system more like being able to interact more with your followers, starting cults in your name, being able to summon them like paladins or demons, things like that would've been good. As it stands, the only reason they are around are as a tack-on.

Magic in this game is like a joke thats been told by Dane Cook - we've seen and heard it before, its boring and it was done better by many, many others. Again, prepare to shell out the souls or the money to get any power in this. After just fifteen minutes of play my first spell might as well have been me sneezing dangerously at the enemy monsters.

Maybe *maybe* this game will be playable in a couple months, but for now if you need something to tide you over and has a darker style then God of War, go get Dante's Inferno.
Don't need the darker style?
Go play God of War.

reviewText: So far this game looks good, it's decent, even though there are some technical issues. The lack of variety of dungeons and enemies may make the game look repetitive and dull, but I really enjoyed it even with these flaws. The game crashed on me a couple of times but that as well may be my system's fault, however, expect some bugs. I think the game is going in a right direction an if they will enhance the multiplayer system, the game would be almost perfect. The story is kind of non-existent (although with such a gameplay you probably won't miss it), but the idea of the game overall is great. As for this being pay-to-win, I really don't know what to say. If you do all dungeons on a daily basis, you are bound to find really good items which are comparable with the ones from shop (if not even better), so it's unlikely one will be very far behind in the matter of gears. For instance, I found a helm of level 10 which was better than the best helm in the shop which was level 13. The rate of getting souls is decent and it depends on your skill. As you get more combo hits, your multiplier for getting souls will rise, so if you manage to do a lot if hitting without getting damaged (you can block and not interrupt combo), then you may get a lot of souls. To exemplify, I got about 60.000 souls in my playtime. The repairs can be a pain in the ♥♥♥, but I read a tip saying that one should use the lesser quality items they find until they break (as they can be selled at the same price even broken) and use their main gear only at invasion or against bosses. Anyway, had a great time playing the game and since it's free to play, I recommend it to everyone. I'd give it a 8.5/10.

reviewText:
At first, I was enjoying this game. It was fun, it made you feel godly, and it still is a good game, but I have some issues with it.
1. I hate the idea of Durability, it sucks and ruins some of the fun.
2. P2W. That's all
3. Not enough PVP moments.

If you got rid of Durability, made it less P2W and make the PVP quests more frequent, I would PAY for this game. It has HUGE potential that I think could make this game the next Elder Scrolls.

Overall:
Pros:
+Fun gameplay
+ Cool Graphics
+TITANS!!!!!

Cons:
-Durability
-P2W
-Not enough PVP moments.

I give this game a 5/10. It has HUGE potential, but at the moment, it's every other F2P RPG.

reviewText:
Intro
The concept of ascending is literally the driving element of this game and a rather interesting one at that. It takes the idea of taking your champions that you personally build yourself and making them part of your NPC champion army to help out in the crusades.

Ascending is status/power
Ascending gives you emblems you can earn a set for each faction which stacks together and allows you to gain great advantages over your opponents. This is really great for people who like to build up a really great character through constantly resetting your character back a few levels or completely with a transcend.

Transcend is new game+
Transcend resets your guy to level 1 and you start over but you keep souls/elbems this really gives players something to do once they hit the cap. By constantly resetting to level 1 they increase difficulty of the game. Keeping the souls is also a great way for players to have a more smooth sailing the first few times seeing as how you can max alot of spells from the start like seekers which prove very great investments to plow through enemies.

COMBAT:  are awesome in my opnion, enemies will try to circle you and attack after each other in a split sec, or all at once. the damage you get from the AI is alot so it not on of these am a demigod games, where AI dosent do ♥♥♥♥ after some lvls.
MULTIPLAYER: is a bit hard since it just simply magic, heavy attacks, blocks. but somtimes you can get in a good fight depends if the other guy runs around eating villagers to regain the 200+ damage, eating a villagers gives back 200 but leaves you open for 1-2 heavy attacks or 2-4 lights attacks. Allso when you walk around you see other players shades and if they fighting, proplems is no way to talk to them or write unless you friends on steam. only real way to talk to them is when you invade them and try murdere them to claim a shine that grants hourly soul income.
LOOT: you get from defeated enemies are somtimes as good or even better then the ones in the shops. only bad thing is they in poor condition, this can be fixed by using souls or go to the forge at spawn, sell eveything els you wont use or is worse, click on the forge and repair. Now you can go out of the game and it will slowly fix all youre items, only bad thing about the free way is it take long time to fix all your gears 100%. Maybe 8+ hours depends damaged the items was, (keeping ekstra items when repairing will slow it down and take longer time)
SOULS:  are easy to get just kill someone, the stronger they are gives more souls like a enemy player can give 4000-10000 am not quite sure but a bit more then a AI boss. the souls can be used to upgreade youre items like a sword to do more damage and last longer, armor to grant more protections, magic to have shorter cooldown, more damage and can use it more times before needing to wait for the cooldown. the other thing souls can be used for is the shop where you can buy a better armor or wep. i mostly used it to get my dream armor since the upgrades can make it better then most finds, a good armor can keep being the bedst for 10 lvls until you clearly found a better one.
allso what some people think you need to use money for soul to be first ahead of combat. that are a big no its about what you do and how you handle it. and souls came pretty easy for me just kill and dont run past.
RUNES: can depends on the god you alligne with like the light god let you get runes that grants crits (twice damage) and speed on mele weps. Allso some runes you can annoy another player with by either having runes that summons 2-4 ex. wolfs into their would where you get a little bit of souls when they hit the player, other way is telepoting nerby enemies out of yours dimension into theirs, the either bug or funny thing is if he have 7 enemies attacking him and you get 4 to him it gives him 11 enemies but if he uses the same spell he can get rid of maybe 4-8.

the proplems i noticed when i played the game are that somtimes the screens freezes but only very few times (1-2)
the soul income was very little, like it dident even matter.
the enemies are mostly the same but looks like they alligne with another god even thought they only serves the titan.
i allso notices that humans (villagers ) can do quite alot of damage if you dont shake them off, it can make invading alot harder if you stand still for too long.
in invade if you kill the enemy and takes too long to take the alter the enemy will respawn with full health. (invaders dosent respawn the protector does)
enemies can bug out but it was in the beta if it are out of it now. (as said havent played for a while)
combat is geat but it shield enemies are annoying as hell since attacks sometimes dosent even seem to have a effect other then they lose health.

But i like this game and would rate it 10/10 for a free beta.
Hope you guys find it usefull and sorry for my grammer.

reviewText:
If curious as to why they removed the option to buy more pillars during ascension to keep another piece of gear? Idk if that's ever been on the pc version as I played it on xbox 360. I wanted to get into this again as I spent about 200 hours + on this game on the xbox version but I really can't see myself playing this if I have to grind for legendary pieces of gear again after ascending. Anyways Great game for what it was, played it for days on end when it first released

Pros:
+ Awesome Concept:
+ Run around as a giant demi god destroying everything in your path fighting over control of the land against other demi gods from a selection of 3 different factions.
+ Can desecrate absolutely everything in your path.
+ Storyline was pretty interesting
++ Your a ♥♥♥♥ing Demi God
+ Blood
+ More Blood
+ Fun to try and challenge friends against the leaderboards.
+++ In what other game can you grab someone who is about 100x smaller than you and slice their head off of their tiny body with a giant ♥♥♥♥ing sacrifical dagger?
+ Awesome spells
+ Pretty nice looking graphics.
+ Is a great port from xbox to pc

Cons:
- They removed keeping multiple gear slots upon ascension?
-- Heavily Pay to Win Currency System( you can sometimes feel like you're being forced to spend money instead of it being an option).
- Not really any true multiplayer aspects.
--- Not much has changed since I played it on the Xbox.

reviewText: For a F2P game, this is one of the best. It sort of reminds me of Darksiders, in how the combat,movement, and items work. I've had a ton of fun with this game, even though most of it is grinding, but this game is meant to be a dungeon crawler like Diablo, but with a different perspective. The only issues i have with this game, (keeping in mind that it is still in beta) is the fact that your armour and weapons don't last long, and there's no dodging mechanic, while you can use the charge attack as a dodge, it's not as quick as rolling around would be. Targeting would also be a plus when fighting large monsters such as the Ogre Brute. And i LOVE the difficulty of the larger monsters. Very unique experience i must say.

reviewText:
Combines a single player experience with competitive PvP action, and a hoard of RPG content - upgrades, items, spells, stats - into one hell of a good game.

My biggest issue, is the fact the game client loses connection with the Signal servers and then terminates my game. Most of time, upon resuming, the game did not save and often I have to repeat entire boss encounters. At one point I had to redo a dungeon three times on count of this problem. Since the last patch this has not occured yet, so they may have improved netcode stability.

Graphic requirements are still high for a game with average graphics. I notice it still needs optimizations to run more smoothly, and in certain zones the game will have a noticable FPS drop.

Updated(again): With the new patch, the forge can repair all equipped gear in minutes for free. This is a very great boon to gameplay, and now gear is affordable. I now change my review to a thumbs up. I still recommend keeping a second backup weapon incase your durability is low and are on a multi level dungeon.

reviewText: Let me start off saying that this is an enjoyable game. I came to this game by looking for a good free game and i found a great free game. Before i keep on giving it praise i say it has flaws(as all games do they were that really got me). So this is the main one that i was really ticked off with is the combat. Somewhat i would call this a spam the mouse kind of game, now there is magic you can use by pressing f and there is a number of spells you can use but of course which spells you get depends on which god you choose(i will get into that later). which kinda lets the combat pass but really the combat you are using two to three buttons left and right mouse and f. That disapointed me thinking when i was downloading this game that it would have at least more combat actions. Also the soul and or point system. Now i understand the marketing system i understand (especially since its free) but sometimes your armor or sword would break and you would have to repair it. but if you have like 300 points you probably need 3000 points to repair it in which you would be running around with no helmet or chestplate until you get souls (points) but of course you can buy souls in which you see that like oh ok thats fine i wont buy souls no,. sometimes you are forced to buy souls cause if you are fighting ogres with nothing on and with a crappy knife and you cant kill it cause you have no protection and no sword and you eventually have to pay 20 bucks just to at least get descent stuff. Now thats all i found flaws in. Now PRAISE TO ASCEND. Ascend's story is awesome, i am totally pulled and you can get more info on the area you are in which is so interesting.And the choosing your god idea was great on how choosing what kinda of feats and spells you have. And i love the chests in which i think its a great way other than using souls to get swords armor etc.  And the enemy damage is fair not ridiculous especially the bosses its fair not ridiculous (not saying its challenging).I will give ascend a 7/10 with an outstanding story but with a couple flaws. thanks for reading

reviewText:
Ascend: Hand of Kul is a cool little game with issues and a review update
Hack and Slash with deity over tones.

Create your demigod and choose which god to follow. Light/Void/Dark.

Now go forth to the land below and convert to your cause.

As you arrive, tiny people from the local village begin to attack. CONVERT TINY PEOPLE AND WORSHIP ME!" Of course they do because tiny people do not like to be stomped on or eaten which is an option if you so choose.

So the tiny people worship you and it's funny when you run around the land
date: tiny people follow.\n\nJust then demons and such
hoursPlayed: arrive to stop you and so the hack and slash begins. Lots of it. Basic arcade style hack and slash. It's not bad
voteText: it's just there is not much to it. Hack and slash your way through the land all the while converting until you defeat KUL who is the cause of the mess.\n\nNow for the issue. Signal Studios did not finsih this game. Technically Ascend: Hand of Kul is still in beta and the devs "kinda" put it on the shelf to work on later. The story goes that the devs moved on to another game and supposably will return to finish up what they left. I could be wrong
helpfulPercent:
but I'm not holding my breath for their return. There are some glitches and hickups here and there. Typical beta problems. Also there is a bug that makes it difficult to save the game.

So why am I playing this game and recommending it?

I'm an easy going gamer and able to over look glitch and bug issues. Although I do have my limits. One game comes to mind that I stopped playing due to gaming issues and that is X-Rebirth.  Ascend: Hand of Kul is no where near as bad. Also
votesHelpful: the problem with saving the game has been solved with a little trick. Always exit the game by pressing Alt F4. What ever reason this corrects the saving problem.\n\nSO! If you can over look minor glitchy

reviewText: It's probably because I'm spoiled by Dark Souls' combat system, but I feel like this game has a very slow combat system. Your Caos moves slow, there's no dodge option, and there's no running, save for a small dash. The combat system seems a decade behind its time, and the gear you acquire through chests does not compare to gear you can buy through micro-transactions. Sure you can grind your way up to buy the gear, but it will take more time than what it's worth, and time is money. This is definitely a pay to win game, although I didn't fight any ascended with insane gear, but if you look at the champions sitting at the sanctuary, you'll know how they acquired the gear. I don't reccomend this game because it is not something I enjoyed, but try it out since it's free, and maybe you might have a different opinion.

reviewText:
I'll divide my review in sections, so you can jump to any particular section of your choice. There is TL;DR section at bottom.

We'll begin with:

[GRAPHICS]
The game boasts of decent graphics as evident by the various screenshots, it runs smoothly for the most part with some occasional flutters. But since this is in beta, it's kinda acceptable.
3.5/5

[STORY]
The game has a decent story line. The world is up for grabs and 3 Gods are vying for a chance to reign supreme over them. You are their envoy called as Caos. Each god has distinct features, powers, and blessings bestowed upon its followers. As a Caos you induce your God's faith in people by showing them might. Although I haven't played much, the story is quite rich. However, it's just not gripping enough to actually suck you in.
3/5

[GAMEPLAY]
Gameplay is very simple, the ye olde Hack n Slash game with some spells added in and one twist. The twist is that each player plays in a parallel universe and they can interact with other players by means of Curses or Blessings, Curses go for enemy players and Blessings for allies(same God followers). It's addictive gameplay, however its somewhat evident that the game was meant to be played with a console gamepad. Occasionally the controls are unresponsive.
4/5

[ECONOMY]
I am an avid F2P game lover, and before jumping into any F2P game, I check its economy rating. The economy in Ascend is rather simple. Everything can be bought with Souls"

[OVERALL| TL;DR]

reviewText: This game feels like Darksiders or God of War in certain aspects, especially the executions. The Combat is smooth most of the time, except when you fight too many ranged enemies. The problem here is that the combat gets repetetive very quickly, as you fight the same enemies over and over again with little to no variety until mid to late game. Each type of weapon has its own moves which makes it slightly more fun , but in the end, only few weapons are actually worth to play with. I have seen so many negative reviews based on the fact that you cannot afford to buy anything because you have to repair your gear all the time and i wanted to clarify this. The combat in this game has a combo counter where each 10 successful hits in row without being hit yourself ( you can block enemy hits, it wont stop the combo. ) give you + 100 % more souls for the kill, therefore if you kill Ogre with a 70 hit combo, you get 600 % amount of souls ( Ogre gives 1000 souls when killed with no combo. ) which is 6000, this amount can repair most of your gear if its not absolutely destroyed, i should also mention that enemies like the Ogres and other boss-like enemies are behind every corner, that is why you can get as much souls as you want, you just need to fight well. I want to mention Boosts as well, they usually give you 30 minute Boost of some kind, i was using the Gear protection Boost most of the time because you cannot damage your weapon or armor while it is active, therefore you dont need to repair it, there are many kinds of boosts, attack speed or cooldown reduction for example. As i mentioned early on, the game gets repetetive and boring very quickly, you have to clear the same dungeons again and again to open never ending amounts of doors so you can continue the story line just to open more doors. I have also suffered from disconnections from the server each 20-45 minutes, which results in the game crashing most of the time, and occasional freezes during loading . PvP in this game makes you fight against enemy bots, to defend your own shrines, which is , at least for me it was, very easy, they are bots after all, and i never even died in this game.If you get damaged, you can just dash away, regenerate, and try again, so there is not much difficulty here. Overall its not a bad game, its free to play and beta after all, but it simply does not do anything special . 7/10
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
=========== The Good ===========
- Fast paced
- F2P. Microtransactions are rather useless. It's NOT p2w! Just rush to endgame (around level 20-25) and then run the infinite dungeon for enormous amounts of souls. The shop looks like a huge joke. The shop also has no items that you couldn't get anyway the normal way by spending like 20 minutes extra which saves you ~5$.
This is the only reason why I upvoted the game. A game that costs no money at all and which is not p2w can hardly be downvoted.
- Controller support



=========== The Bad ===========
- Sending enemies to other players is silly. They can banish them back. And then you banish them back again. This useless process repeats until one of the two players doesn't want to buy anymore Banish spells. But in worst case you just run out of agro range, heal up and kill them.
- If you lose connection to the servers (for any reason including server problems) then you may also lose the progress of the last ~10 minutes of gameplay.. Including dungeons or altar and whatelse AND you may lose certain buffs that you had 10 minutes ago but that now mysteriously disappeared.
- Crashes sometimes. But it's beta so okay.
- Relatively low graphics.
- Having to redo your appearance and to select your old gear again all over every time you ascend is plain annoying.
- Has almost no content.
Higher level dungeons are exactly the same as the ones on lvl 1 only this time they added a few extra mobs... Even the layout is the same. Often the 2nd floor in a dungeon is EXACTLY the same as the 1st floor... Only with a different boss at the end.
Bosses are also re-used all the time.
- Dashing + [X] is the fastest way to travel. The downside is that is hurts your fingers after several hours of mashing. 3 buttons just for moving around. And the regular movespeed is so incredible slow that you really want to dash + [X].
- Repairing is just annoying. I wish there was an auto-repair feature.
- The minimap is small and the big map is annoying to navigate to using a controller.
- After about 30 minutes in the game all the way to endgame every fight feels the same and it becomes extremely repitive. Mainly because there are a few overpowered moves/spells that you will use for everything in the game.
- Has no 'epic feel'. You can't dual wield 2 huge axes or hammers like in Dark Souls.
- Bosses that instantly turn around 180 degrees and hit you. Like the bear-mini-boss that falls down and at the very last moment just before he hits the floor he turns around 180 degrees and hits you even though you where standing BEHIND it.
- Hitboxes that are off. The Ogre's for example attack forward and hit you even though you are standing safely behind them without even touching them during any animation. Not to mention that these guys sometimes also instantly turn around.
- The server lags a bit when you use a super fast build. Corpses may spawn in the wrong location and such.



=========== The Rest ===========
- Extremely unbalanced. This can be either good or bad depending on what kind of player you are.
You can become so fast that no mob can hit you, you can pretty much perma stun bosses at low level and heal during most fights by just walking back a little so that the boss loses agro. Or just walk out of agro range so that any boss adds no longer agro you.
Also invaders can be stunlocked and killed without taking damage at all.
- The game is extremely easy and you will steamroll all the way through it. Might be interesting for casual players. But for die-hard players this is just not worth playing anymore after like 1 hour into the game.

reviewText:
Ascend is a hack and slash RPG made by Signal Studios, the makers of the Toy Soldier games. This game is great, and when originally released on the Xbox 360, I played this game like mad.

The main premise is that you a Caos, a giant divine being, that is working for one of the New Gods to reclaim the land from the Titan, a Old God that now just a husk of evil due to being corrupted by the world of man. There are 3 New Gods for you to choose from: Dark, Void, and Light. Dark Uses the power of fire, and improves you melee combat by increasing damage and armor. Void uses ice, and makes your magic stonger and giving you evasion. Light uses lightning, and increases movement speed and crit chance.

The combat in this game reminds me of the first Fable actually. It uses the simple weak attack/strong attack that many games use. You can also throw spells into the mix. When a emeny is low enough on health you can execute them, which has multiple animations depending on what weapon you are using or the enemy you are fighting, which gives you bonus XP. The enemies also level with you, so you cant really just faceroll through the game. You can also go through dungeons, which give loot at the end and are a randomly generated layout. There is even a endless dungeon you can go into.

The multiplayer in this is interesting, having two different types of interactions. These interations can be influenced by the players themselves, or by AI. The player to player interactions are somewhat minor, but you can mess with/help people. To mess with people, you can send enemies from your world into another players world, or summon your own enemies straight into their world. As the enemies do damage, or even kill the other player, you get rewards. You can help other players by dropping buff fountains into their world, which gives them the specified buff for a good bit of time.

As you play through the game you build shrines for the god you follow or capture alters for them. As time passes, these will get attacked by other players" trying to convert it to their god. This also happens while you are not playing

reviewText:
Definitely worth a try, you might fall in love.

I started playing this the day it launched here on Steam.  It had a few issues, but none of the issues you'd expect out of a new launch.  The servers were fine, there was very little lag, and I didn't have to wait for a year to log in.  It didn't send me out of game to create an account for their website, like so many games do, either.  All of these things were a very nice surprise.

The game itself is a hack and slash not unlike things like Dark Souls.  In fact, Souls are actually the currency in this game.  It sticks to the next-gen'ish gameplay that we've been seeing lately :  Single Player with a mix of leaderboards and invade style" multiplayer PvP.

The combat is fun

reviewText:
Ascend is a hack and slash RPG made by Signal Studios, the makers of the Toy Soldier games. This game is great, and when originally released on the Xbox 360, I played this game like mad.

The main premise is that you a Caos, a giant divine being, that is working for one of the New Gods to reclaim the land from the Titan, a Old God that now just a husk of evil due to being corrupted by the world of man. There are 3 New Gods for you to choose from: Dark, Void, and Light. Dark Uses the power of fire, and improves you melee combat by increasing damage and armor. Void uses ice, and makes your magic stonger and giving you evasion. Light uses lightning, and increases movement speed and crit chance.

The combat in this game reminds me of the first Fable actually. It uses the simple weak attack/strong attack that many games use. You can also throw spells into the mix. When a emeny is low enough on health you can execute them, which has multiple animations depending on what weapon you are using or the enemy you are fighting, which gives you bonus XP. The enemies also level with you, so you cant really just faceroll through the game. You can also go through dungeons, which give loot at the end and are a randomly generated layout. There is even a endless dungeon you can go into.

The multiplayer in this is interesting, having two different types of interactions. These interations can be influenced by the players themselves, or by AI. The player to player interactions are somewhat minor, but you can mess with/help people. To mess with people, you can send enemies from your world into another players world, or summon your own enemies straight into their world. As the enemies do damage, or even kill the other player, you get rewards. You can help other players by dropping buff fountains into their world, which gives them the specified buff for a good bit of time.

As you play through the game you build shrines for the god you follow or capture alters for them. As time passes, these will get attacked by other players" trying to convert it to their god. This also happens while you are not playing
date: so land will be captured even when you are not playing. When you defend your shrine/alter
hoursPlayed: another players Caos will drop in to defend/attack. Now these Caos are AI controlled
voteText: but they are outfitted in the gear and spells they had equipped when the other player Ascended (which I will explain later). While yes these are controlled by the AI
helpfulPercent: they can still be quite difficult to fight
votesHelpful: since they may have better gear and spells. The AI also somewhat adapts to how you play
votesTotal: by blocking more if you are hyper aggressive
votesFunny: or by breaking your guard if you are overly defensive.\n\nThe unique thing about this game is that your character will Ascend
commentsCount: which you can do every 5 levels. Ascending does multiple things
column16: with the most straight forward one being raising your level cap to the max level of 60. (The initial level cap is 20) When you ascend
column17: you sacrifice yourself
column18: and create your character anew. This allows you to customize their appearence again
column19: as well as pledge allegiance a different New God if you want. You keep your old gear
column20: but have the option of buying different gear when creating your character again. Once you are done making your new character
column21: you will be exactly where you were as the previous character
column22: so story (and thus unlocked areas) progession isnt lost. Now you will have a Ascended Champion
column23: which invade other players worlds in the gear and level they were at the moment of ascention. (Which I described above) They will fight for they god they were devoted to at the time of ascention as well. As they do this
column24: they will earn you souls as well. So as you play through the game
column25:
you will be making a army of former characters.


The real money aspect of the game (that pretty much every F2P game has) is that you can spend real money to buy souls. You use souls to buy/repair gear and to buy spells
column28: etc as well. This isnt much of a big deal
column29: since you will be making souls by simply playing the game
column30: earning more as you level. Because of this
column31: the real money aspect isnt much of a problem
column32: so it doesnt really ruin the game.\n\nI highly recommend this game."

reviewText:
GAMEPLAY : 8/10

Ascend : Hand Of Kul is originally a Xbox 360 exclusive game and is now ported to PC via Steam.

This game is basically a spiritual successor to the Souls series,you could see some of the similarity when you start playing this game.

This game is heavily single-player focused so you don't have to worry about lagging though the game is build on a shared-world ( basically you will see other players entering the same world as you did ).

As you start off the game,you are given a default Caos ( your character ) and 3k souls ( which is basically in-game currency,you can purchased additional souls with real money too ). From there you able to buy different type of hairs,face,facial hairs,skin colours,armor & weapon.

You are given three option to choose which path you want to go ( Darkness,Light & Void ). Each of them have their own unique benefit and able to grant you new spells that the other path doesn't offer.

The game tutorial is very well done.

You have different types of weapon which some of them have longer range & other short range but deal extremely high damage.

The combo system is kinda basic i would say since there is only few different type of combo you could perform.

As you go further into the game,you able to invade many realms & areas. Some of them give you benifit to call your little army. This tiny people will aid in your combat though it pretty useless at the sametimes cause it deal little to no damage to the enemy. The only best things is to eat them to regenerate your health when you are low on health.

The game has durability system which done very poorly.  Your armor & weapon will break more often and repairing is very costly when you need the souls to buy stronger equipment. But do not worry though,the game have chest that scattared around the places so you don't have to worry wasting your souls just to repair your equipment.

The game is pretty linear but it had some little exploration.

You can also perform finishing moves as well on your foes and this will grant you additional health & experience points.

GRAPHICS : 7/10

The game look pretty decent for a low budget title.

Character models,terrain,texture details and environment is very well done. Though some of the area & world can get pretty dull and some of them have repetitive environment.

AUDIO : 7/10

The soundtrack for this game fit very well with the settings.

Voice acting is not bad.

The sound effects is decent.

LONG-LASTING APPEAL : 5/10

Can't say that this game offer much replaybility.

Once you completed the game,you can try out different paths to test out different spells.

The game is pretty straightforward with no additional side quest to do.

There is a PvP mode too but this will happen random times when other player trying to invade your realms. You can try to grind for levels but it doesn't serve much purpose.

The game also have survival modes you unlock as you progress through the game.

PvE would be a nice touch but it seems that this game doesn't provide any at all.

FINAL VERDICT : 6.8/10

I say give it a try for those who like hack & slash game.

The combat system can get stale after sometimes but it pretty enjoyable nonetheless.

The game is violent at times but it not God Of War level of violence.

Developer will include new areas in the upcoming updates.

GRADE : D ( Not Bad )

reviewText:
While the game may have a good basic concept, it's execution is nothing short of faulty. In some respects it actually perfectly fits the Pay 2 Win bill. And I don't throw that around lightly.

Basically, you are some kind of pseudo-giant whom's single purpose is to follow a lineair path set by the story, while claiming shrines along the way for the God you have chosen. This is accompanied by a simple gear & loot system. Chests are scattered across the several maps you have to plow through which often contain mediocre to outright crappy gear for you to wear and use. This enforces the idea that the best gear is bought with Souls.

Souls is the central currency. You earn it by completing tasks set before you, dealing with mobs and some such.
But you can also simply buy it for real life cash.
That's right. Not only can you buy the best gear available to you at any point in the game (the game even pauses) but you can skip the grind entirely for it.

And this fact has become very obvious in my first few hours of gameplay. You see, the shrines you conquer for the Questline can actually be contested by other players. When this happens, an NPC of their character comes and fights you for it. Losing equals to losing the shrine, which means you lose some vaguely described buffs.
Now, for a level 6, that NPC looked strangely well equipped. Compared to my honestly grinded character, at least.

BUT it doesn't end there. Nooooo. You see, players who are treading the same path as you are shown as 'phantoms' that are color coded according to their chosen God. One feature is where you can buy Curses and Miracles, or whatever the buff things are called. The name doesn't matter because Curses are what it's all at.

Buy a curse for souls, at any point you please, target another Caos (that's the race you play as, not a typo) and presto, you can spam them with countless of high powered mobs (the curses have limited usage per purchase). Do that in an area where you know shrines are going to be contested, and you've got some rageworthy situations where it became nigh impossible for me to even move on with the quest because the NPC and mobs kept killing me. Let alone win my Shrine back. And death refills everyone's health, but fleeing refills the NPC's as well.

What Ascend has here is a very elaborate system that encourages both Pay 2 Win as well as persistent trolling.
If you want a game where your money can make people miserable, Ascend is the way to go.
Straight up, go do it. Do your best to make people miserable in this game. The more you do it, the bigger the chance this atrocity of a game will collapse onto itself. Do it for your next of kin, as if that would ever be a reality.

As said, the base concept of this game has potential. But it fails brutally in it's execution. The fact that it even rewards P2W by listing the top players as the 'Champions' of their respective Gods is nothing short of a slap in the face. Because you know these are the players who have really cheesed it out and gamed the system to it's maximum.

Unless all of these aspects speak to you and you've got some weird masochism thing going on, I really don't recommend playing this game. Free To Play has long stopped being a valid excuse to give a game a pass.
These games commonly have cash shops which should make them subject to the same standards as full-priced games do.

And the word Beta stops having any meaning when the game starts charging you money for anything.

reviewText:
I can't, as of yet, recommend this game. The combat's fine, if a bit easy against regular AI enemies. Spamming left mouse and dash attack makes it almost impossible for them to hit you, while racking up your combo counter.

The combat in the PVP doesn't seem like it's working as intended. It seems that blocking is incredibly good right now, because using Strong Attacks to break the guard doesn't seem to ever hit, or very rarely hit. Over a few pvp fights, only one strong attack actually connected. The others flew right through the other player. I don't mean it missed, I mean it literally swung through the player, and didn't hit them at all.

On the positive side though, the cash shop is fine. You can pay to get good equipment from the start, but you get plenty of souls, the currency, just playing the game. Your combo counter goes up, the more times you hit enemies without being hit, which in turn multiplies the amount of souls you get for killing enemies.

The game's in beta, as it says in big fat letters on the title screen, so this is all based on the build of the game that was first made available on Steam.

reviewText:
I love this game style, the grind, the boss battles, etc... And resently i have gotten pretty far for a (noob) person who's played this much of it. But I have been noticeing once you hit a certain level the sould become harder to get, Thats becasue at the higher level its more expensive to repair I get it. But the prices can be redicules sometimes. <<<SIDENOTE>>> THOSE WHO SAY THAT THIS GAME IS PAY TO WIN ARE DUMB ASSES!! The sould you get are around 10-20 per mob on a normal kill. But here are the reasons its not a pay-2-win

1) souls are the only thing you can buy
2) souls are free you infact dont need to buy them at all (like me)
3) the more you hit the monsters the more you get (combos..... 10,15,20,etc,,,,, hits = 10(or how ever many) x2,x3,x4,etc....
4) mobs are NEVER ALONE! (can fight in pack from 2 - 20)

Ok, so enough of that.... this is the part where I dis the game



1) Buggy (I know its a beta but still feels like I should be in alpha) getting stuck in walls, or like me UNDERGOUND.
2) Stupidly high prices on crappy stuff(but you can find a epic deal here and there)
3) Having the honor" to face people that are level 30+ (with their gear and add +'ed so high)
4) combat is still a little clunky

So that is my reveiw on the game (the graphic are ok but i can care less of how good they are comapred to other game).      (I dont judge the game by graphic like kids now a days. i judge it on the content). If you would like me to explain more on how the gameplay is or if your stuck at a certain boss please dont be afraid to Add me. Other than that this game is great and i will rate it at..... 8.5/10"

reviewText: The game is fantastic. Basically all you do is run around going on a killing spree taking Troll Souls. You’re like a giant Badass ginger. The game also likes to lead you into a false sense of security, you play a while, think you’re doing good and that nothing can stop you...BAM! A giant with a hammer bigger than you shows up and you’re suddenly fighting for your life. In this game you can't underestimate other player either. Somebody could be level 3 and you could be level 5 thinking ha-ha easy, but that might not necessarily be true. The player could have Ascended at some point and be at level 6 with stuff far better than yours. Overall the game is stupendous and has a bunch of great features. I highly recommend getting it. It’s free so you have nothing to worry about.\n10/10

reviewText:
Combat feels nice against random mobs as you wipe out groups of 30+ goblin-esque creatures, but when you're matched against a much larger enemy the flaws in the shallow combat really show.

Larger enemies that have the ability to really put damage in have really quick attack animations with seemingly no stopping to their swings. (They're also really into the idea that when they knock you on the floor they're allowed to keep swinging to wipe out a full health bar.) Blocking these attacks puts you into a stun animation (as well as a bit of chip damage) and knocks you back. These two components mean you have to then rush forward to get damage off, but these enemies have perhaps half a second of rest before they attack instantly again. (Fun fact: You can sit on the edge of their aggro range and wait for the auto healing to fill up your health bar as they do nothing till you're back in range of their aggro.)

Therefore, you rely on magic! Which does no damage.

Perhaps if you stick forward for 900 hours of this shallow M1/M2 mashing you might get to the point where spells are an effective combat technique, but for early game these larger battles serve more as a way of brutally pounding your ♥♥♥♥ with little way of enjoyably taking on enemies.

In short. ADD A ♥♥♥♥ING ROLL BUTTON.  10/10

reviewText:
Note: This review is based on the game as it stands at the time of review. The game is listed as a Beta, and I fully understand expect that many things in this review will be improved upon as the game is worked on. This review is regarding whether you should play it *as of the time of the review*, and has no bearing on the future. I may revisit the game at a later time to update the review.

The first thing you probably want to know: Is this free-to-play game pay-to-win? Can people buy their way to being stronger than everybody else? Well, while there is nothing that cannot be earned through playing, you can acquire almost anything you want by paying for it. XP boosts, stat boosts, better equipment, better spells, all of it can be acquired by paying. Of course, there are some things you'll need to actually play for; there are some stat increases you can only get through ascending (a sort of new game+-lite feature), you cannot straight-up buy levels, and equipment available to buy (or find) is tied to your level. While there is currently no PvP (only PvAI where the AI controls another player's character), there will be in the future. I haven't played this game on console, so I don't know exactly how it will be, but from what I see, the upcoming PvP will be very much pay-to-win. Even the invasions, where AI-controller players take control of your territory and you must defeat them to regain it, can be incredibly difficult against opponents that have paid. The fortunate thing is that these invading characters don't level up, so you can level up yourself or acquire better gear in order to defeat them.

Now, the gameplay. Think of it as a stripped down version of Darksiders, which is like a stripped down version of Devil May Cry. You have light attacks you'll spend all day spamming and heavy attacks you'll only use to break guards, as that's all they're really useful for. You have spells you can use freely, with only their cooldowns and charges limiting them; some of them are unwieldy to use and very weak, and in general the spells are fairly unspectacular. You can also block, which reduces (but doesn't completely eliminate) the damage you take from non-heavy attacks and spells. Ultimately, it largely boils down to button-mashing with the occasional block, dash-attack to escape, and spell to keep enemies at bay.

The dungeons are very much all the same. There are a few different layouts that are recycled over and over with different skins on them. All of the enemies, chest locations, and bosses are generally the same, as well. It's Dragon Age 2-level of environment recycling.

Enemies are both incredibly boring and frustrating. You'll see the same half-dozen enemies over and over again, with hours between seeing anything new. The weak enemies are complete pushovers, while the stronger ones are almost unreasonably powerful in comparison. As far as bosses, the hit detection on their attacks is awful, such that their attack will hit you without their weapon coming into contact with you, even if you interrupt the attack with a spell, so long as their attack begins. There's very little variety in bosses as well; you'll end up seeing the same bosses over and over and over again, with no differences except being a higher level. Even the big" bosses

reviewText:
Looking at the trailer, and the photos I was expecting a good rpg. When I got the game I was disappointed. Let's see why:

Graphics: 3.5/10
I didn't really see a discernable difference between Antialiasing on and off. It looks like a game from 2006, as the graphics remind of TES IV: Oblivion. There was nothing noteworthy at all. At the start of the game you create your character through various preset heads, hair, face, etc. But looking at most of the textures it looks blurry on my laptop. Now this maybe my laptop you say but it's not. My laptop could max out CRYSIS 1-2 with CRYSIS 3 at HIGH. The world doesn't look taht good either but it looks better than the rest.

Gameplay: 5.5/10
Graphically it may suck, but gameplay wise it feels like GoW, which is good combos aren't bad. But I expected more out of it. My main problem is when it came to the controls. It feels like a console game. Because its a port of a console game. That's basically why I deleted it. It didn't feel like a PC Game. It felt like an Xbox Live title. (Not that there's anything wrong with XBL titles) But playing games like on this on my laptop is frustrating since i can't plug my WIRELESS xbox controller to my laptop. Arguably you could just rebind the controls but I don't know, it just didn't help for me. Also from the chracter creation, It was already obvious, this is P2W (Pay to Win) kind of games. But its not that insulting" compared to other F2P games out there. And since I refuse to GRIND and waste my time getting better items
date: since it is obvious that the key to winning is BETTER items.\n\nI know this game is still in beta but I really couldn't get into the game that much. I know a lot of you will enjoy this type of game
recommended: (especially since its free) but for now unless it gets out of beta skip the game
