reviewText: As I am currently playing this I can't in good concience to tell anyone to play this why? Because Pay to Win rears it's ugly head. Please don't stop reading after the Pay to win statement I know it get's thrown around a lot and in some cases unjustly please just read on.\nI really enjoy this game. I have have done well so far but here is the problem. I started at launch on Steam. So I have been playing for a good bit in two days I think however I just recently ran into a guy who's avatar has been wrecking me. Why? Because he purchased a ♥♥♥♥ ton of souls and is unstoppable. The main currency in this game is souls. Infact there is no other currency. Use souls to buy spells use them to buy gear! Congrats you win! If you grind for a while you will not be getting an obscene amount of souls I have spent around 200k souls and only have about 5k on my character at this time. To give you an idea I spend about 8k to fix a broken weapon or armor. However with just a small purchase of $75 you get 750k WOOO that means you can ascend choose a god buy all the spells you want from it then once you get the strongest spells that you had to do nothing for you except progress the story which will be ♥♥♥♥ing easy because you just buy the best gear you can ascend again! Then choose another god and buy all the spells you want again! YES I have officially bought my way into power. Now I can go back to the god of my choosing and keep all the spells I just purchased and then buy all the best gear from the market place cause hey it's cheap when you just blew 75 bucks on 750k souls! So the main issue you if you introduce pvp all the poor kids or people who are responsible with money and can't just through into a fire will be ♥♥♥♥ out of luck. I like this game it is fun but this kind of market will destroy a communite and turn people away from your game. I know the agruement will come up oh you know you can just play through and farm end game while that is true. If you are getting your ♥♥♥ stomped at every turn losing the land you fought hard to get against someone who just bought whatever they wanted why play? Why should player be interested in playing a game that he could never do well at because someone in a higher income bracket just buy the best ♥♥♥♥ in the game and just beat you. Don't like ♥♥♥♥ing get over it is a usual response but that is no arguement. So don't bother with the same old internet trolling.\nAgain I like this game but they should re work the market to make it fair. There are minor other issues but those are expected in beta so I won't bother addressing them as they are being worked on. But so far no mention of the glaring issue. the market.

reviewText:
I will explain exactly what will happen to you in this game if you play it for free.
At first you will have fun and be killing monsters and reading mildly intresting lore.
Then you will be doing dungeons you may think they are a little bland but you dont care much because the combats fun.
You will ascend and only keep one piece of equipment and start to understand how you will be progressing.
You will have to start repairing equipment and your flow of souls(money) will slow down because they are overpriced to repair.
Then after you have a few areas under your control you will start being invaded by npc challengers in these areas and will probably have fun fighting them.
You will fight an overpowered boss that takes forever while the game wants you to waste souls on upgrading equipment you wont keep.
You will be invaded by someone's npc who has obviously payed for all purple and yellow equips and they are way more powerful than you could possibly be at this point.
And after all of this you will get tired of the game and realise that its pay to win.

Oh yeah and this is all while you are being cursed by ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s 10's of levels higher than you with monsters you could never possibly kill.

Edit: i forgot to mention that if they can fix the prices on repairing then it would fix most if not all of these issues.

reviewText: I know there are a lot of people who don't want to read a lengthy review so I'll just give a little summary.\nThe concept for the game and some of the mechanics are very interesting and show a lot of promise such as effecting other peoples worlds by sending minions to attack them and watching their ghost die horribly as you unleash a horde of ghouls on them. However the game is extremely poorly executed, the controls are very clunky and extremely unresponsive which is a third-person beat-em-up game just isn't acceptable. The graphics are rather nice nothing super special but it certainly isn't an eyesore like many free to play games you see. The absolute killer for this game is if you want to actually get good gear for your character to play though the game you pretty much need to hand over cash to get items when you create your character. Would I reccomend this? to someone I dislike, Yes, to anyone looking for a fun free experience? no, I'd advise avoiding this until they make some changes.

reviewText:
Very interesting little game. I enjoy my time with it and you like combat-focused games this is the one for you.
The combat has a nice flow to it, the equipment system is fairly simple and the multiplayer aspect is... Interesting... I rather enjoy screwing people over and it somehow reminds me of Dark Souls' Invading mechanic.
Only gripes is that, other than fighting there's nothing else to do, which isnt exactly my cup of tea, but if you're into that - good! Also I suggest playing this with a controller, while the keyboard works fine, the menus' are fairly annoying for a mouse.
Overall, would play, but nothing exceptional.

reviewText:
Wow, THIS is how you do a free to play game correctly!
Not only is this fun but the money you spend truely is optional!

Graphically - Nothing is going to blow your hair back. It does the job and runs very smoothly. Blood and gore along with some good sound design work well. I love hearing your half god breath, he sounds massive.

Mechanics - This is where the game shines. You play a 'half-god' for one of 3 other gods. From what I can tell you are fighting in real time, other players for territory for your god. Light, dark and void. When another player 'invades' you shrine you have the option to take them on one on one. Its very fulfilling to pull off one of the many finishing moves against a human opponent. Not only that but there are these MASSIVE Titans running around. So far I havnt killed one yet but I am slowly taking over his territory.

Now, as far as I can tell the goal is to 'ascend' up to your god when you are ready. Your avatar will join the gods said army in the battle over territory. Now, I have only ascended twice and each time you are asked if you would like a different god to worship. I've stuck with the 'god of light' for he grants you speed.

Im only 3 hours into this and it took everything in me to put it down. I'm really enjoying it and you might too if you like hack n' slash RPGs. I mean it is FREE after all.

reviewText:
This game is amazing, I used to play it on the Xbox 360 a lot around a year and a half ago and then I saw it was also on steam, so I downloaded it. When I got into the game I realised it was in Beta so I did some research and heard that the game got discontinued, I continued to play the game and saw how many hours I had already invested into this game (303.7 hours on the Xbox) I noticed that the game got increasingly boring after I leveled up my PC character to level 32, (keep in mind I have never payed any money for this game, (this game is NOT pay to win) I realized that I had outplayed the game and that it had come to a point where I felt like I needed to stop playing. Here is a list of why the game got boring and why I stopped playing it.

- The PVP was too easy

- The PVE was repetitive

- Your character becomes OP after about 24 hours of gameplay and leveling up

- The storyline was also pointless so it became a chore to make a new character if you wanted a new one

- And there is no  level capping in PVP

Despite the things that happen over time as you play through the game, I will always love this game and all that it stands for. And who knows maybe I'll come back someday.

reviewText:
Note: This review is based on the game as it stands at the time of review. The game is listed as a Beta, and I fully understand expect that many things in this review will be improved upon as the game is worked on. This review is regarding whether you should play it *as of the time of the review*, and has no bearing on the future. I may revisit the game at a later time to update the review.

The first thing you probably want to know: Is this free-to-play game pay-to-win? Can people buy their way to being stronger than everybody else? Well, while there is nothing that cannot be earned through playing, you can acquire almost anything you want by paying for it. XP boosts, stat boosts, better equipment, better spells, all of it can be acquired by paying. Of course, there are some things you'll need to actually play for; there are some stat increases you can only get through ascending (a sort of new game+-lite feature), you cannot straight-up buy levels, and equipment available to buy (or find) is tied to your level. While there is currently no PvP (only PvAI where the AI controls another player's character), there will be in the future. I haven't played this game on console, so I don't know exactly how it will be, but from what I see, the upcoming PvP will be very much pay-to-win. Even the invasions, where AI-controller players take control of your territory and you must defeat them to regain it, can be incredibly difficult against opponents that have paid. The fortunate thing is that these invading characters don't level up, so you can level up yourself or acquire better gear in order to defeat them.

Now, the gameplay. Think of it as a stripped down version of Darksiders, which is like a stripped down version of Devil May Cry. You have light attacks you'll spend all day spamming and heavy attacks you'll only use to break guards, as that's all they're really useful for. You have spells you can use freely, with only their cooldowns and charges limiting them; some of them are unwieldy to use and very weak, and in general the spells are fairly unspectacular. You can also block, which reduces (but doesn't completely eliminate) the damage you take from non-heavy attacks and spells. Ultimately, it largely boils down to button-mashing with the occasional block, dash-attack to escape, and spell to keep enemies at bay.

The dungeons are very much all the same. There are a few different layouts that are recycled over and over with different skins on them. All of the enemies, chest locations, and bosses are generally the same, as well. It's Dragon Age 2-level of environment recycling.

Enemies are both incredibly boring and frustrating. You'll see the same half-dozen enemies over and over again, with hours between seeing anything new. The weak enemies are complete pushovers, while the stronger ones are almost unreasonably powerful in comparison. As far as bosses, the hit detection on their attacks is awful, such that their attack will hit you without their weapon coming into contact with you, even if you interrupt the attack with a spell, so long as their attack begins. There's very little variety in bosses as well; you'll end up seeing the same bosses over and over and over again, with no differences except being a higher level. Even the big" bosses
recommended: are almost completely identical to one another.\n\nThen there's the sound. Your weapons
hoursPlayed: all of them
voteText: sound like hollow metal tubes hitting wood
helpfulPercent: regardless of what you're hitting. The music is at least alright
votesHelpful: though.\n\nThere is a 3-sided war that overarches the game
votesTotal: with players choosing one of three gods to follow
votesFunny: aid
commentsCount: and gain power from. You're told when you initially make the choice that it is permanent
column16: however you can choose whichever one you want each time you ascend. In fact
column17: you're losing out if you don't choose each god at least once
column18: as that's the only way to gain access to that god's spells. It makes the war between the gods completely pointless if people can choose whatever side they want almost without restriction at any time.\n\nIt's also worth keeping in mind that this game requires you to be online. Losing your connection will cause you to disconnect from the game
column19: wiping out the progress since the last save. Luckily
column20: the game autosaves fairly frequently.\n\nThis game still needs a lot of work to be in a state that I would deem worth playing. If you're interested in playing it
column21: look at the date of this review and check what's been done with it since."

reviewText:
Looking at the trailer, and the photos I was expecting a good rpg. When I got the game I was disappointed. Let's see why:

Graphics: 3.5/10
I didn't really see a discernable difference between Antialiasing on and off. It looks like a game from 2006, as the graphics remind of TES IV: Oblivion. There was nothing noteworthy at all. At the start of the game you create your character through various preset heads, hair, face, etc. But looking at most of the textures it looks blurry on my laptop. Now this maybe my laptop you say but it's not. My laptop could max out CRYSIS 1-2 with CRYSIS 3 at HIGH. The world doesn't look taht good either but it looks better than the rest.

Gameplay: 5.5/10
Graphically it may suck, but gameplay wise it feels like GoW, which is good combos aren't bad. But I expected more out of it. My main problem is when it came to the controls. It feels like a console game. Because its a port of a console game. That's basically why I deleted it. It didn't feel like a PC Game. It felt like an Xbox Live title. (Not that there's anything wrong with XBL titles) But playing games like on this on my laptop is frustrating since i can't plug my WIRELESS xbox controller to my laptop. Arguably you could just rebind the controls but I don't know, it just didn't help for me. Also from the chracter creation, It was already obvious, this is P2W (Pay to Win) kind of games. reviewText:
Only checked out a little of the game (finished the tutorial and a few things). Seems pretty solid. Controls are a little meh, gameplay is pretty okay. The only real gripe I have is about the sense of scale being a little screwy. The world seems you sized, so the tiny human peons come off more as the brownies from Willow than anything else. All in all however, I see a lot of potential. I probably won't play it again, but I can see this game being a big deal for a lot of people.

On a final note: The cash shop seems reasonably priced. A few bucks gets you a set of gear (or haircuts or whatever). Granted (as is always the case with cash shop games) some items are just silly expensive, but it doesn't come off as pay to win.

I'd give it a solid 7/10. If the controls were a little tighter and the scale a little better, easily an 8/10.

reviewText:
This game is pretty sweet - fun game play, variety of melee/spell combos, deep lore, buff dudes:

This very cool game has GOD of WAR style gameplay, where you play as a CAOS, a giant and powerful champion and servant to  a Trinity of new Gods.  In the Local/Single Player Game you progress through a relatively linear map, winning over lands for your chosen god.  Once you reach a certain level, you are given the option to Ascend (ie., bascially physically die and your soul lives on). Your ascended being (or soul) fights on you and your chosen god's behalf against other real players. (This is basically an AI with your skills, gear, and perhaps some playstyle characteristics.)  This is the global game.  Though, some of what is happening behind the scenes is unclear.  For instance, you can direct your ascended champion to take an area on the map,  But I'm never sure if he's taken it or not - maybe it's still in development.

The game is very fun and has great lore overall.  This game also has a big selection of gear you can buy with the souls (currency) you collect fighting creatures and bosses.  ((Boss fights are awesome, BTW!))  Weapons and gear can be slotted with runes to augment their power or add abilities.

There is a lot to be built on here and I hope they keep expecting.

IF ANY PRODUCERS READ, Suggestions:
MORE, Longer Combos please.
+ Combos that incorporate spells
I would love to see a wider selection of spells and spell skill trees (spell runes??? :)
Also just more runes.
I'd love to be able to talk to other players visible in the world, and to watch my ascended champs fight live.
Jumping, or no?

reviewText: This is a fun game. It is fast paced, easy to access and play, and has some interesting unique gaming concepts. You are a demigod of sorts initially born from the prayers and pleading of worshippers. When you awaken" you are given some limited options for character customization and then selection of armor and weapons based upon your play style. Weapon animations differ depending on the weapon type you choose. The attack sequences are familiar to us all who have played action based games in the past. Light attack
recommended: Heavy Attack....combos with the mouse. Left click
hoursPlayed: left click
voteText: Right click. And different variations. Light
helpfulPercent: heavy. Light Light Light Heavy
votesHelpful: and so forth. You get the picture. You are lead through a very linear path completing objectives while being told a story. All the while you are fighting monsters in a limited destructable environment. As you kill things you collect experience and "souls"
votesTotal: which are the currency of the realm used to repair and purchase items and spells
votesFunny: which you use to increase your demi-gods abilities. You are given various challenged throughout while playing.\nOne of the games unique aspects is your ability to effect others games. You don't exactly play alongside anyone. What is going on is you can sort of see a ghostly outline of other players who are in the same area as you are but in sort of a seperate instance. You see them fighting but don't exactly see what they are fighting. Its sort of like you are aware they are there without actually "being" right there with them. You will understand if you play it. But anyways
commentsCount:
you see this other player fighting and at the same time maybe you are fighting as well. You have the ability to open a portal to the other players realm and send the monsters you are fighting to him in order to add additional difficulty to his fight. You are rewarded for any damage those monsters do to the enemy player. This is referred to as a "curse". There are options to "bless" or help other players but....I mean who does that? (evil grin)

The pay model is very forgiving. Its free to play. You can go from beginning to end and not pay anything if you wish. Or you can buy in game currency from their cash store to purchase items. These are the same items you can get normally.

Its a fun game that doesn't get deep into your pocket book. But these guys deserve some monatary support for their work which may not be skyrim great but its better than most of the crap we see published today. Their thinking outside the box in some concepts should be rewarded lest the gaming industry devolve into infinite EA sequals selling us the same game over and over again. Halo 12

reviewText: It's rare that I play something truly unique, but this is one of the better ideas I've seen. Take the online elements of Dark Souls minus the messages, mash them together with God of War, and then throw in some diablo-esque loot and dungeons. In addition, you're required to ascend periodically, which involves giving up your character and starting over, but with perks. You don't lose everything when you ascend, and you get some unique stuff that can only be gotten by ascending. You also don't lose all your levels, but you do increase the level cap. PvP is largely hands-off, involving cursing players of opposing factions by sending enemies from your world to theirs or summoning creatures to attack them. The game also has a bit of strategy in that areas you've claimed for your faction can be attacked by ascended characters, which then gives you the option to fight them directly to defend your land.\n\nIt's really a great game, and I can't understand why the developers appear to have abandoned it. Check the Discussions for common complaints and bugs. There are a few serious ones. If they fixed them, I'd gladly pay $20-30 for this.

reviewText:
The concepts of this game are for the most part uninspired, which wouldn't be an issue if the game was any good.  It takes from games like dark souls with its invasion system, planetside with the 3 factions trying to take over areas of the map, and any number of generic fantasy 3rd person camera button mash-athons.

The invasion system however has problems take over an area and at random times you get invaded having to defend them and that’s it, as their doesn't seem to be a purposeful invasion system.  You may not even be fighting a personas they can in fact be AI's as if have seen my AI was defeated once I ascended.

The 3 factions also don’t work when the game is entirely single player.  No; this is not a joke, there is no co-op and the only other thing to indicate multiplayer is the minor invasions which take you out of the area to defend then bring you right back to where you were without the enemies.

All of these however are not the biggest issue I have with the game which is in fact the pay-to-win feel I get.  Souls are the only source of currency for everything; repairing easily damaged equipment constantly, upgrading your equipment, and upgrading spells.  This wouldn't be a problem if the amount of souls you got from enemies would be able to exceed the amount needed to be able to repair and upgrade to some extent rather than feeling desperate for souls.

So I spent like $13 dollars got some of the souls and started to feel like I was OP after upgrading.  This all came to a crashing halt as I got the ogre where I got destroyed with no real way of being able to beat him.  The game even would bug out so that he would be immune to taking damage every other time I died.  So if I died once I might as well just die again as his health bar would go away from the screen and nothing would matter.  But that reminder of upgrade if you're having problems kept showing up and so I gave up since a game with this bad of a paywall" isn't really going to ever be worth it in the end.

I won't even really get into the flat graphics
date: or illogical world design around the "caos" rather than the humans or titans
recommended:
or the boring combat with just button mashing as this review is long enough.

Sorry for being so long but this is what I experienced in short bad paywalls/ pay to win/ breaking glitch with ogre/ lack of creativity/ poorly uninspired concepts taken from other games that do them better.
"

reviewText:
Pros:
-The game is pretty addictive.
-Combat is repetitive (If you keep using the same type of weapon) but fun and satisfying
-Different type of weapons have different play styles.
-Gears look badass, even the low level ones.
-Asending mechnic is pretty innovative.
-Not exactly pay to win, and I didn't have to spend a penny. The in-game currency is earned pretty fast.

Cons:
-Lack of Enemy types.
-Sometimes Bosses just get you stuck in a corner with invisible walls and keep attacking you until your miserable death.
-Horrible UI interface.
-Combat still gets repetitive even though it is fun and satisfying.
-Other players' characters controlled by AI during invasions weren't very chellanging.
-If invasions were done by real human players, would be much more fun.
-The ability to call for those tiny archers is pretty much useless.

Final verdict: 7/10
Not fantastic but still worth playing since it is a free-to-play.

This game is complete garbage... 100% garbage and 100% pay to win.

Oh did your item just break? Oh well give us money and we'll fix it for you."

reviewText:
On the surface and at first glance this game seems solid and fun. Tiny humans can ride on your back shooting enemies. Totally rad. You are a giant monster man killing things and destroying nearly everything. Also rad. There is a global war between the factions and it's persistent which is also really cool. However, the game is total crap. Dont let the fanboy types fool ya.

First, the “free to play” model is BS. The cost in souls (in game currency) is out of control. Your gear loses durability faster than anything else ive seen in other games. And fixing it is EXPENSIVE. To make matters worse, even new gear you find in dungeons comes nearly broken and needs to be fixed. Dont want that gear? Sell it, for a whopping 100 souls (cost ya 1k+ to repair it or 5k+ to buy an equivalent from the store lol).

Second, if you log out you have to start the story over again when you log in. This was the true game breaker for me. I didnt just spend 5 hours working on the story just to start over cause I went to bed. WTF. I get it, you are supposed to ascend your guys (turning them into a NPC and start over new) and thats cool. But I wasnt ascending, I was logging out. That is anti cool and not even a little bit fun.

Lastly, the persistent war isnt as cool as one might think. You can be attacked by other players (cool) and instantly teleport and defend your area (also cool) but dont expect to win. All the people who are foolish enough to spend money will CRUSH you. Not to mention the three times I was invaded the invader was 3-5 levels higher than me. Yay.

On a side but related note, I read that this game is no longer supported by the developers as they have moved onto a new project. That alone should tell you not to spend money. I am a big fan of supporting my “free’ games (have spent thousands of dollars on League of Legends for example) but that is only when I expect consistent developer support and/or game improvements.

So heed my warning and dont waste time with this game. I really wanted to like it but it is 100% pass. Even for the low, low price of free (which ultimately it wont be).

reviewText: Great game, lots of fun details (i.e. eating the humans riding on your armor for health), and is well finished for a beta game with an interesting story and only a few bugs that I've noticed. Lots of people complaining about P2W, and it is a bit, but honestly it's single player, you're not affected by P2W if you don't want to be. Downsides is that it becomes a bit repetitive after a while (kill some trolls, do an objective, kill some trolls, fight a boss, kill some trolls) but combat is fluid and fun, so I don't mind. Bossfights remind me of Infinity Blade (If anyone's played that), blocking or dodging depending on the attack and spamming m1/m2 after an attack chain. Bosses are reasnobly challenging and I've heard some of the later ones would not be out of place in Dark Souls. It's free and only a gig or so, just get it and try it.

reviewText: Being a huge, godlike being and trampling human villages to dust sounds fun? Well, yeah, it is!\n\nIf you are looking for an action-title to kill some time and enemies, this might interest you. The combat feels fluid and is simple yet interesting enough. Being made for a console initially, the controls are ported pretty well to the PC, so I never had a problem playing with my keyboard. There are various mechanics to influence the game for other players near you via gifting" some of your enemies to their realms or blessing them. Those elements really bring some dynamic into the game. The second big thing are your crusaders. At certain levels
date: you can decide to make an image of your character which will be sent to others games and invade their villages. If successful
recommended: this grants you more resources to equip or train your character.\n\nThe whole game is free to play and there is nothing in the game that would allow for pay to win. All you can buy is souls
hoursPlayed: which are obtainable in the game by playing and in plentiful amounts!\n\n7/10 and a lot of potential left."

reviewText: I would say this game is similar to Dark Souls, but it's free to play! The enemies in this game truly pose a threat to the player as you venture through the land trying to convert the people there to worship your god that you have sworn to serve under. The bosses in this game are a real challenge. Timing is crucial, don't be hasty or your battle will surely result in your defeat. Blocking and dodging are a big part of staying alive in this game, you can't really be a tank" in this game. If you get hit too much your equipment loses it's durability and requires repairing. Repairing consumes souls
date:
which can result in an insufficient amount of souls.

The Pros:
-Challenging
-Moderate paced gameplay
-Amazing finisher animations
-Variety of weapons to use
-When you kill something
recommended:
you FEEL LIKE YOU KILL IT

The Cons:
-Repetitive
-Souls can prove hard to obtain
-Repairing equipment often
-Not much of a multiplayer system
-Fustrating battles

Cons:
- Combat feels clunky and is not fleshed out at all
- Combat is not balanced: monsters often knock you back far and quickly, which means you'll be reliant on spells to kill them (which are on a long cooldown). Get down for loooong boring battles
- Absolute PAY2WIN. There is no separation between ingame currency and bought currency: it's all souls. The more money you pump into this game the better gear you have.

Obviously any game that is pay2win (a game in which you can buy power for real money) is simply ♥♥♥♥, so definitely not recommended.

reviewText: I had read about this game in game informer and thought man
date:
that sounds like a really great idea"  and then randomly ran across this game thought nothing of it and then thought about it and was like HEY THATS THAT GAME!!! so I promptly downloaded it and fell in love.  There is no pay wall.  The multiplayer and pvp are not really there so they are not to overwhelming to the learning curve but if you want a more hands on approach with your pvp this is NOT the game for you.  But I love the MP/PVP elements very Dark Souls in nature

I absolutely freaking love the idea of retireing your champs regularly to have them go raid other peoples games.  I really enjoy it when I get a msg that says hey you are getting invaded and I drop what I'm doing to go make sure I don't let my territory fall to some other guys Caos.  It probably also helps that right after I first ascended a caos (read new game+) the first msg I got after making my new avatar was "Demon has taken an alter from XXXX" I was so proud of the little big guy.

I can see how this will get repetitive if I let it but its a great hack and slash adventure.

I really dig the story and the heavy wolf theme

The 2 direct interactions with other players are cool:
Curses send baddies into someone elses game
(I've had some ppl put expertly placed curses while I am fighting a boss to get me killed I think they get bonus points for that) (I *Think* I've gotten one other person killed but idk and idk what I got for it if I did)
Blesses drop a totem for the other player to pick up and range from hp boost to speed boosts and who knows what else in between.

All in all I really dig this game.
"

reviewText:
This is a weird game, though weird's not bad. It feels like Darksiders-inspired combat and art style met the Souls' series doom and gloom and constant hungering for souls, with Warhammer Fantasy as the lore backdrop.

You are an immortal spirit that serves that new gods that lives in the bodies of giants,  'Caos Warriors.' You choose a deity, and try to take over the world in their name. Your choice of deity gives you your narrator, as well as abilities you can learn throughout the course of the campaign. From there, you charge off into the game.

Combat is action style. Combos are very simple at the moment, but I imagine they could add more in the future. You have quick attacks, the number of which you use resulting in different heavy attacks, a block that works against most abilities, a dodge, and your selection of spells. Every once in a while, when prompted, you can also tap E to do a finisher on an enemy to regain HP. More hits without getting hits gets you more combo points, more combo points get you more souls when you kill stuff.

XP from kills gets you levels. Souls buy you weapons, armour, certain spells (most are earned via plot), spell upgrades, and item upgrades, and are also used to repair, and upgrade current items. Now, you CAN buy souls for real money, but store items are randomized and level locked, so that'll only go so far, though...

Every few levels, you can shed your body and 'Ascend' it, sending it to Crusade on behalf of one of the New Gods. This is not a handwave to explain a new game plus-esque feature. You lose some levels and your inventory. However, you can use your souls to purchase legacy pillars, and add some of your items to your permanent inventory. You also send your body to one of the gods, and it will actually be able to appear as a random bossfight for other players, capable of earning you and your god rewards. You can also realign to a new god at this point, allowing you to mix and match spells.

Dungeons are randomized once a day, and a special item must be purchased with souls to enter dungeons not of your alignment. If you follow Void, you can't enter Blood or Light dungeons without buying a Mask of Blood or Mask of Light. Many spawns and bosses are copy pasted, but these encounters aren't bad, per se, and the addition of other players roaming around can lead to some interesting trouble.

You can see the 'ghosts' of players in the same zones as you are, coloured by their deity alignment. You can use 'curses' to send them more enemies to fight, or 'blessings' to give them bonuses such as more exp or better spell recharge. More in depth co-op and PvP options are also 'planned.'

It's derivative of a lot of things, but I think it's an interesting game worth the look, and considering the entry price is 'free' and the download isn't even that big, the only thing you've got to lose from giving it a shot is time. I label it as an okay time killer for now, but this is beta, and I could definitely see it growing into more.

reviewText:
What we have here is an attempt to merge single player with multiplayer.  They will tell you that this is a great thing, and that it's free to play, and that even if you're a terrible player you will be able to ascend over & over to become great one day.

Nope.

This is simply another Pay-2-Win.  The currency is souls, which you harvest from killing.  However you also get them from spending cash.  You need souls to repair weapons, to buy character options, to buy weapons, to upgrade spells, to purchase buffs, and to purchase temporary spells that allow you interact with multiplayer.  If you don't do this, you will hit situations where your gear will not be up for the challenge, and you will be repetitively ganked by the game or other players.

But even if cash weren't an object, it's still nothing to write home about.  Combat is extremely limited, as is mobility.  The controls are clunky.  Ulimately you're wandering around, taking waypoints to gain territory, killing titans, and enslaving humans.  You get to battles with your own kind, in which the player who has spent the most cash will inevitably prevail.  Rinse & repeat.

reviewText: I wanted to enjoy this game more than I did, but I ended up getting to frustrated at the combat system. The game itself is minorly confusing to begin with, but I'm used to that with a lot of the F2P games. I can get over that. What tipped me over was when I was fighting a bigger monster and it was about impossible to kill. The action genre of combat they've chosen for this game is very lackluster. The doging isn't particularly good or effective and the frequency in which the bigger monsters attack makes it almost impossible to actually hit. So you get stuck hitting once every few minutes while praying you held block to block the basic attack and hoping he doesn't use a heavy one. All in all, it has potential as a system, but I wouldn't recommend it with the combat as it is. It is also slightly pay-to-win in that the main currency (souls) can be bought with real money and be used to purchase better gear.

reviewText:
This is a weird game, though weird's not bad. It feels like Darksiders-inspired combat and art style met the Souls' series doom and gloom and constant hungering for souls, with Warhammer Fantasy as the lore backdrop.

You are an immortal spirit that serves that new gods that lives in the bodies of giants,  'Caos Warriors.' You choose a deity, and try to take over the world in their name. Your choice of deity gives you your narrator, as well as abilities you can learn throughout the course of the campaign. From there, you charge off into the game.

Combat is action style. Combos are very simple at the moment, but I imagine they could add more in the future. You have quick attacks, the number of which you use resulting in different heavy attacks, a block that works against most abilities, a dodge, and your selection of spells. Every once in a while, when prompted, you can also tap E to do a finisher on an enemy to regain HP. More hits without getting hits gets you more combo points, more combo points get you more souls when you kill stuff.

XP from kills gets you levels. Souls buy you weapons, armour, certain spells (most are earned via plot), spell upgrades, and item upgrades, and are also used to repair, and upgrade current items. Now, you CAN buy souls for real money, but store items are randomized and level locked, so that'll only go so far, though...

Every few levels, you can shed your body and 'Ascend' it, sending it to Crusade on behalf of one of the New Gods. This is not a handwave to explain a new game plus-esque feature. You lose some levels and your inventory. However, you can use your souls to purchase legacy pillars, and add some of your items to your permanent inventory. You also send your body to one of the gods, and it will actually be able to appear as a random bossfight for other players, capable of earning you and your god rewards. You can also realign to a new god at this point, allowing you to mix and match spells.

Dungeons are randomized once a day, and a special item must be purchased with souls to enter dungeons not of your alignment. If you follow Void, you can't enter Blood or Light dungeons without buying a Mask of Blood or Mask of Light. Many spawns and bosses are copy pasted, but these encounters aren't bad, per se, and the addition of other players roaming around can lead to some interesting trouble.

You can see the 'ghosts' of players in the same zones as you are, coloured by their deity alignment. You can use 'curses' to send them more enemies to fight, or 'blessings' to give them bonuses such as more exp or better spell recharge. More in depth co-op and PvP options are also 'planned.'

It's derivative of a lot of things, but I think it's an interesting game worth the look, and considering the entry price is 'free' and the download isn't even that big, the only thing you've got to lose from giving it a shot is time. I label it as an okay time killer for now, but this is beta, and I could definitely see it growing into more.

reviewText:
Why no fem Caos? And not a single arguably female character other than the hot boob goddess. Even all the puny ant people are obviously masculine. You can try and defend this as a part of the game universe like woah all the womens got wiped out and we now reproduce asexually and/or are created/spring out of holes in the ground but there is no evidence of this in the game lore.
Ignoring the gross lack of diversity, a few gameplay features make it fun and different but in the end it's not worth it. Possibly worth trying since it's free but I still don't want to support or continue investing time in this game.

Plus the long main menu loads are annoying.

As a beta release, it's possible that things may change but nothing has been addressed officially as far as I know/care to look deeper for.

reviewText:
This was showing potential for an enjoyable enough game.  Then you get what little player interaction that happens happen when you have to defend a holding from another player's ascended.

I've never become so ragingly angry at a game before.

What should be a highlight feature is so horrendously unbalanced that it's impossible to win.  I'm amazed anyone finds it enjoyable.  I'm amazed anyone can beat these without cheating.  Every attack you take flinches you.  You block and retaliate, use a combo with a heavy attack, which the game says to use against blocks to break them, and the AI ignores it.  They don't flinch.  They just start comboing you.  You take damage before animations even begin.  You react to them using a heavy attack, it's instantly blocked.  In fact, everything is instantly blocked.  You actually GET a combo going, you've suddenly taken damage from nothing, and then you're flinching again, until you block, they ignore your heavy, and you're dead.

This isn't lag.  This is just dumb.  This is some of the absolute worst balance and design of what should be a fun feature.  I tried 30 times.  Even careful, even predicting to my absolute best ability, it just didn't matter.  Combos were impossible to make.  The enemy would simply ignore being attacked, then stop you from being able to attack back.  You'd get something off and somehow they use a heavy strike while being pummeled.  You use a heavy strike?  Flinched out of it.  They're blocking and it lands?  They hit you anyway.  The only way to win is to massively outgear the enemy.

Don't even bother.

reviewText:
This is a weird game, though weird's not bad. It feels like Darksiders-inspired combat and art style met the Souls' series doom and gloom and constant hungering for souls, with Warhammer Fantasy as the lore backdrop.

You are an immortal spirit that serves that new gods that lives in the bodies of giants,  'Caos Warriors.' You choose a deity, and try to take over the world in their name. Your choice of deity gives you your narrator, as well as abilities you can learn throughout the course of the campaign. From there, you charge off into the game.

Combat is action style. Combos are very simple at the moment, but I imagine they could add more in the future. You have quick attacks, the number of which you use resulting in different heavy attacks, a block that works against most abilities, a dodge, and your selection of spells. Every once in a while, when prompted, you can also tap E to do a finisher on an enemy to regain HP. More hits without getting hits gets you more combo points, more combo points get you more souls when you kill stuff.

XP from kills gets you levels. Souls buy you weapons, armour, certain spells (most are earned via plot), spell upgrades, and item upgrades, and are also used to repair, and upgrade current items. Now, you CAN buy souls for real money, but store items are randomized and level locked, so that'll only go so far, though...

Every few levels, you can shed your body and 'Ascend' it, sending it to Crusade on behalf of one of the New Gods. This is not a handwave to explain a new game plus-esque feature. You lose some levels and your inventory. However, you can use your souls to purchase legacy pillars, and add some of your items to your permanent inventory. You also send your body to one of the gods, and it will actually be able to appear as a random bossfight for other players, capable of earning you and your god rewards. You can also realign to a new god at this point, allowing you to mix and match spells.

Dungeons are randomized once a day, and a special item must be purchased with souls to enter dungeons not of your alignment. If you follow Void, you can't enter Blood or Light dungeons without buying a Mask of Blood or Mask of Light. Many spawns and bosses are copy pasted, but these encounters aren't bad, per se, and the addition of other players roaming around can lead to some interesting trouble.

You can see the 'ghosts' of players in the same zones as you are, coloured by their deity alignment. You can use 'curses' to send them more enemies to fight, or 'blessings' to give them bonuses such as more exp or better spell recharge. More in depth co-op and PvP options are also 'planned.'

It's derivative of a lot of things, but I think it's an interesting game worth the look, and considering the entry price is 'free' and the download isn't even that big, the only thing you've got to lose from giving it a shot is time. I label it as an okay time killer for now, but this is beta, and I could definitely see it growing into more.

Every attack you take flinches you.  You block and retaliate, use a combo with a heavy attack, which the game says to use against blocks to break them, and the AI ignores it.  They don't flinch.  They just start comboing you.  You take damage before animations even begin.  You react to them using a heavy attack, it's instantly blocked.  In fact, everything is instantly blocked.  You actually GET a combo going, you've suddenly taken damage from nothing, and then you're flinching again, until you block, they ignore your heavy, and you're dead.

This isn't lag.  This is just dumb.  This is some of the absolute worst balance and design of what should be a fun feature.  I tried 30 times.  Even careful, even predicting to my absolute best ability, it just didn't matter.  Combos were impossible to make.  The enemy would simply ignore being attacked, then stop you from being able to attack back.  You'd get something off and somehow they use a heavy strike while being pummeled.  You use a heavy strike?  Flinched out of it.  They're blocking and it lands?  They hit you anyway.  The only way to win is to massively outgear the enemy.

reviewText: Interesting concept, and fun to play. However, once I finished the tutorial, I was immediately attacked by a player who was a much higher level. He was a paying player who waited around in the starter area to harvest low level players. This is a huge turn off for me and makes the game unplayable. The game is still in beta, so hopefully this will be fixed. For now, I would not recommend this game for the reasons stated above, but, this may change in the future.

reviewText:
An ok game, but brought down by average design, troubled by unclear rules, and riddled with bugs.

It must be strange why someone would play for some 60+ hours this and come out with a negative review.
Well, that is because as I just transcended for the first time I began to see things happen that were not written anywhere of how they would go down and I realize I was setting myself for more trouble than necessary.

First of all, I just want to get this out of the way: People complain tons about the game being pay-to-win. No, it's not. If there's something I must say in favor of the game is that I needed not to purchase a soul pack. I played just fine through the game, never saw any progress walls"

recommended: all by playing the game normally and not even being actively farming for souls. I understand the game suffered changes with time

While graphically the game isn't terrible (not bleeding edge

reviewText:
I don't even know where to start....

I originally downloaded this free to play game when I was big on xbox360. I very much enjoyed it and even supported the game by purchasing souls, even though I felt they were a bit pricey, the game had a charm to it that simply grasped my attention. I foresaw this game becoming something big; it has such potential story wise. Giving it a go on PC a year later, I see nothing but the same unpolished game as I saw on the 360. What happened? Did they just say forget this game" and leave it running to collect money from people buying souls?

I start the game only to constantly be invaded

reviewText:
Dont waste your time.
It's just a line-slasher with donate and dangeon-system.
You think im wrong?
Gameplay - kill enemy, go to here, kill 40 enemy, wait new wave, kill enemy, sometimes you take a message about invated on your shine/village. You see Player-nick... but its just a bot, not real player, they lie.
Economic  - You pay sort of 2k+ soul (in game gold) for repair One item and after all you can (will) sell it for 30 soul.
One dangeon give to you ~1k soul (full clear dangeon) - you lose sort of 25-50% durability.
Remember you have Weapon, Chest, boot, glove...
Rpg - you have three path(god-fraction) warrior like a Darkness(best imho), wizard like a Void (i played), and Warrio-wizard? like Light. not matter - you always will attack with basic and basic.. and basic... now you know who best in this game.
Something else? - no, it's all what you find here.
Oh sorry i forget about Multiplayer - You always will be playing solo, boss, creeps-mobs... always the one.
Other people can pay sort of 500-1000 soul for Summon add creeps-mobs enemy for you (Just imagine you have 10-20% hp and fight with Hard-boss (some like 95% boss) and some man who just walking around summoning other !(3)! ENEMY one type Just for Fun he get nothing. Also if he have other type you take 6 enemy creeps-mobs and more) - it is your multiplayer in game...
I dont know what say else.
I recomend game because i pretty sure you didnt go to negative comment.

reviewText: I originally played this game on the Xbox 360 and had a lot of fun with it. I eventually deleted it because of long load times but, I'm glad that that isn't the case with the PC version. The graphics are good and the gameplay is a hack and slash kind of like Ninja Gaiden. My one problem is the keyboard and mouse controls, the original key bindings make you use the entire keyboard so you have to move your hand off the WASD keys and the mouse pointer felt a little stiff. I would recommend getting an Xbox 360 controller because those controls are perfect. Sometimes bosses can be hard but they always have a set area to where you can just move in and out the area and use your spells to kill the boss. Hope this helps.

reviewText:
Here's an honest opinion about the game:
On the pro side, i enjoyed the brainless hack and slash thing pretty much, with basically the items you pick up in treasure chests in dungeons you can slay countless mobs with ease and I was able to farm up upto 80k souls because of the hack and slash thing.

The cons are, when you're given the moment to face bosses and semi-bosses, you're gonna be in for an unfair surprise. The unfailry buffed hp bar, move set which is too agile for big monsters and I dont understand why blocking doesnt really do you good as it breaks and still damages you. You may say Oh you just need skills to do beat bosses"
recommended: but each time i dodge sprint (because there is no dodge roll) an attack
hoursPlayed: i can't go back in for hits because the recoil time for the boss' attack is fast and I'd say ♥♥♥♥ you if you tell me I'm just noob coz I finished dark souls 1 & 2.\n\nGraphics looks ok
voteText:
but i get low frame rates on my laptop. I run dark souls 2 in high fine with 30fps but here i get sub 20 in a clash of skills type of scenario with maxed up settings and lowering it doesnt get me up to 40+ fps.

I understand it's in beta so I'm giving it a 4-5/10
there is much much more to improve on but this game packs potential.

Giving this a "Not recommend" until fixes are done."

reviewText:
This game is strangely addictive, I enjoy playing it thoroughly and while my review most likely will not be read by anyone who is makeing the game itself, I hope atleast someone listions to it c:

Basically, the game is a hack and slash, you run around and complete quests for the god of your chooseing:

Darkness
Void
Light

Dark and Light being clear in their intent Void is more the neutral party. After sideing with a god you then go on a series of missions, and wanting to get ever stronger the game quickly turns into wanting you to spend money to get good, I've spent quite a lot, and while it's fun, ultimately the games Ascending screws you over with paying. Ascending is somewhat flawed at the moment and I believe it's being worked on, but the fact that you pay quite a bit for points, and you lose them all so fast only to be forced to ascend past a level cap and lose the things you spent the points on (that you didn't sell) is fairly un-fair.

On a different note - the game is somewhat lonely, you have human allies and enemies, their neat and it's cool when some of them have actual roles and personalities in the campaign, but this is a big world, and your human allies are sort of just human allies, no magic, just some swords, spears, and bows. Enemy humans are actually allied with the enemy Titan's minions and it seems rather unfair you never get to see those same minions on your side, while you can still send them to attack other players on a plane seperate from yours. It's sort of like the game is teaseing you in that regard.

A caos is basically a super-sized human with tons of power and some cannibalistic tastes, you can actually eat anything tiny, includeing your own allies, considering the campaigns premise that there is a gigantic war going on, you hardly ever see any actual war, between the human tribes or even the monsters, not even any rival monster battles, to show the intensity of the situation. Generally you just see neat little skirmishes.

Caos are tanks that destroy everything and their by themselves, it would be nice to have to take down one of your big boss enemies, meanwhile get to sit back and sorta watch units fight, atleast as a passtime that is kinda enjoyable, or see the humans more active in say, trying to attack or press forward into enemy territory or do something by themselves, just for atmospheric purposes.

This game is awesome, but it is still in Beta, and for a Beta, it's pretty awesome, I would deffinately reccommend this, but just know how stuff is layed out in the game at the moment, a lot of stuff seems like a money grab, and the game gets fairly repetitive and boaring after a bit, which was why I was giveing some ideas to make it more interesting and enjoyable c: I hope that atleast someone finds this helpful or interesting, or gives the game developers some ideas, because this game is great, but how it is right now needs work.


7.5/10 ^^

reviewText: This game is awesome up to a certain point. After a few hours worth of gameplay you practically NEED to spend money on souls (ingame currency) in order to upgrade your gear / buy new gear, otherwise anything will kill you in a matter of seconds and bosses become a giant kitefest that relies on your ranged abilities to wear them down. You CAN grind for the souls (main reason i'm still recommending this game) but it takes AGES to get anywhere near the amounts you need to get any decent gear.\n\nAll in all i'd give the game an 8/10, it's a betagame with huge potential but the sharp drop from feeling overpowered to being shred to pieces in seconds is kind of a turnoff, especially since you need to grind for a couple of hours to get anywher near the amount of souls needed for a piece of upgraded gear.

reviewText:
Contrary to what some people seem to think, this game is fun. Really, REALLY fun. Sure, it has an in game shop that CAN lessen the time you pass in game, actually doing GAME STUFF (This game is all about territory and rebirthing your character to lose a few levels in exchange for more power and an increased level cap, so obviously rushing through the story is NOT the right way to play, rather, you should claim territory, defend it against other players pledged to other gods who want to steal it and then rebirth, changing allegiance to another god then your old one, and retaking all your territory from the ones who were once your comrades.) and skip right to kicking ♥♥♥, but even if you don't, it is quite possible to be more powerfull then someone pouring in hundreds of bucks by pouring in an equal ammount of time.

Pros:

-Interesting story
-Fun PVP system that blends in flawlessly
-Unique point of view (Well yeah, you're a giant who eats humans to restore health... Nice to not be a bad guy but not be a good guy either in an MMO for once)
-Fun and intuitive combat system
-Easy to get into, even if you never played this kind of game before.

Cons:

-Real money shop IS a little invasive, nothing like everquest popups though
-The learning curve is quite steep, making the game rather hard (But some people love that, the souls serie is my proof)
-Some players can be trolls, sending high power monsters into your instance of the world, possibly forcing you to grind more then normally required
-Combat and the territorial system are not very explained, but just enough that you can play.

reviewText: Very addictive game for me. I love the looting and the fact that you really don't have to spend a dime to get what you want, Just hit the Endless Dungeon. Eating and throwing ur food is comical. You are not tied to just one alignment. When you ascend you can change alignments and get spells from that one as well. This allows you to ultimately decide what are all the spells you want to use.\n\nSpeaking of ascending. Basically what that entails is that you decide you have made ur character strong enough to survive the war between the gods as an NPC. You have to make a certain number of levels to ascend and I recommend you save up at least 31k souls. This way you can pass your gear to all your newer characters everytime you ascend as a legacy item. I'll be playing this for a while.

recommended:

It's like Dark Souls partly in the interactivity between players. You'll even see spirit outlines of players near you. They can either benefit you or hurt you.

All interactions are
column17: of course

single-use. I had about 6 "schminvasions" in my inventory and I threw 4 of them at one random guy. I saw him struggle for a bit and then I sent him an exp buff and a magic refresh buff.
I saw him die from a different monster.

column19: you "delete" your guy and it becomes a phantom
column20: which attacks other people's shrines.\nYou'll constantly have to defend your captured zones from AI controlled players that are well-geared. The AI will spam attacks and magic and is

column25: and while you'll hear "different weapons have different combos". In my experience
column26: all the weapons have the exact same combo with slight speed and reach variations.\n\nThe monetization scheme is dangerous. It's subtle enough that you'll buy a handful of (DARK!) souls once and you'll trivialize it over time so that
column29:
$200 in nothing but a handful of weapons or armor you'll discard eventually.

column30: leaving you unable to gather the required souls to repair

After a few hours worth of gameplay you practically NEED to spend money on souls (ingame currency) in order to upgrade your gear / buy new gear, otherwise anything will kill you in a matter of seconds and bosses become a giant kitefest that relies on your ranged abilities to wear them down. You CAN grind for the souls (main reason i'm still recommending this game) but it takes AGES to get anywhere near the amounts you need to get any decent gear.\n\nAll in all i'd give the game an 8/10, it's a betagame with huge potential but the sharp drop from feeling overpowered to being shred to pieces in seconds is kind of a turnoff, especially since you need to grind for a couple of hours to get anywher near the amount of souls needed for a piece of upgraded gear.

reviewText:
First let us get the big reasons this game has as many negative reviews as it does. In Hand of Kul you’re a Caos, a giant being that humans revere to be the heralds of gods. Awesome idea! I’m a giant you can call upon my human subjects and have them fire upon my foes. Awesome. Pay for souls so as to buy up all the good gear and make yourself almost unstoppable. Less awesome. Combat that starts out cool but soon gets repetitive. Less awesome. Your gear degrades so fast you’d swear that it was made of turkey bone instead of steel. Less awesome.

It’s things like these that hold back this game into being something really great. The story in it is less than gripping and also a little off putting. I get summoned down from the heavens, a giant prepared to be clad in armor, armed with a great axe, and spread the influence of my Patron god… only to immediately realize that the Titan, the main villain towers over you like a parent over their child, their magically inclined, axe wielding child, but a child none the less. Then you come to find that the majority of enemies you face are only a little smaller than you some, like the Titan, are much bigger than you. And also all of the dungeons you enter are several times larger than you. Perhaps it could be the lore of the game that they were built by other beings like the Caos, but you never really feel the weight of your size that often, or at all because you’re crawling through a dungeon bigger than you, opening chests just the right size for you and fighting enemies just as big or bigger than you.

That’s not to say that the game isn’t fun. Far from it. It can be fun to fight through enemies in rather basic combat, it can be fun to invoke the spells of your god, raining punishment on your foes. All in all if the game cost twenty bucks on steam, I’d tell you to wait for it to go on sale during the summer or winter. But I don’t need to tell you that. The game is FREE. Some would say that the game isn’t because of the pay2win mechanics going on but it is free. You are required to pay nothing to play this game. Your gear may degrade fast but there are forge’s to which you may repair all your currently equipped gear while you’re not playing. Because of this I feel that Hand of Kul is a game you play in bursts. Free as it is, play it once. Find it’s just not your cup of tea just uninstall it, nothing lost.
As it is though, Hand of Kul is an okay game with some problems; at the price of free it’s worth at least a glance.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game is still in beta, but I quickly found out what this game is all about: Money.

Why do I say this? Because everything involving this game revolves around a currency that can be bought with real world money. Skills, weapons, armor, runes (which are used to enhance armor, but once socketed to an armor piece they can not be removed for use with new armor), weapon and armor upgrading, and buffs (yes... you are charged for buffs). I will mention that the prices for things are pretty ridiculous and you will be grinding. Also, if you pay with real money expect to get a meager amount for your purchase that allows you to most likely get one or two items or to not even fully upgrade one skill (unless you're insane and willing to spend $100s on the game...).

You will also be constantly repairing your gear, another cost, which isn't cheap when you suddenly find yourself with 2-4 almost broken pieces of gear.

The other negative part worth mentioning about the game is that it is super instanced and you will constantly be seeing a loading screen. That and the graphics are super outdated looking, it's as if I've rewound time every time I play this game and have suddenly gone back to 2008. Textures are really, really ugly for a 2015 game.

I would honestly not suggest this game. It is clearly just another attempt to milk people's wallets with a horrible monetization system.

reviewerDisplayName: Dr. Rockso; Rock n Roll Clown
reviewText:
The Gameplay is very fun and engaging, think Dark Souls but as a more forgiving MMO.

Now for the bad.

The game has glaring technical issues. There is very frequent disconnects experienced by many community members not to mention the fact when you try to log back in the game fails to connect to the servers. Then after you spend about 10 minutes trying to do every technical fix suggested on the forum you still come up empty handed.

Gameplay wise I give this a 8/10
but overall due to the technical issues I give it a 3/10 it's only saving grace is that it's a fun game when you can actually play it.

reviewText: Played the game quite a bit on Xbox before it came out on PC. And I gotta say it is actually pretty enjoyable,all thou you can tell that it's F2P from sheer cost of the cooler stuff. Combat is good,nothing groundbreaking but good,bunch of combos for melee and you can spice things up with spells of your choosing,they are locked to a faction but they do carry over whenever you ascend your character,ascending creates new character and destroys the old one,allowing you to carry 1 item over and letting you choose faction again.\nThere is no real time pvp,only pvp is done against bots that have the body of previously ascended character of a player,but not player himself.\nI remember spending about 15 euros on this game back on console and did not run out of ingame cash anytime soon, I have not played the game recently but I HOPE this would still be the case,if they went buy to win somewhere along the line then it would be a terrible shame,as it stands from my experience I can recommend the game.

reviewText: Ascend: Hand of Kul is a mixture of Darksiders and Dark Souls combined with its own unique twist. Some people would probably say God of War but so far I've only had one quick time event....and that was pressing X. It was pretty intense and I nearly failed it (yes I'm being sarcastic). The good thing about Ascend is they don't shove buying souls on you. So far I've made the mistake of spending a ton of souls on instantly repairing my gear without knowing there was a repair station at the Sanctuary. Of course it'll take a whole lot longer but it beats being desperate for souls. There doesn't seem to be any real story to this game other than the fact that you're a Caos who pledges himself to a God and can ascend into another life and be reborn". Your goal is to take shrines and towns and spread darkness
recommended: or void across them. Each God has his/her own perks and drawbacks.\n\nThe combat system again is a lot like Darksiders. Some low health enemies can be executed for a small health boost and it all works on an X
hoursPlayed:
Y combo system. I don't know how it works for PC controls since I plugged in my 360 controller and this is how I play. Bosses can be very annoying if you're backed into a corner or just knocked down. Which is where the Dark Souls bit kicks in. Small enemies easily stagger you and big bosses easily knock you to the ground. When at low health your Caos will limp making it a lot harder to get away and stay alive. The most unique thing about this game is you can use your worshippers to attack enemies and eat them to keep your health up...and throw them because it's kind of funny. Puny humans.

This game requires an internet connection like Dark Souls; and you can see other players in your region and know who joins and leaves but you cannot directly affect them. In order to help or cause other players harm you need to have a blessing or a curse or you can use your ascended Caos' to attack areas taken over by the other two opposing Gods.

Overall
voteText: it's really good for being in beta and can say it'll be one of the best free to play games on the market. The only problem I've had is periods of freezing for a short time and I did crash once while desecrating a shrine (heh that rhymed). I recommend downloading this game and can't wait for what the final product will bring."

reviewText:
Best game I have played in a while. Highly addicting I just Can't seemed to put it down.

Pro - Great RPG/Hack and slash fun.
Pro - Leveling up dosen't take forever and the ascend ability is awesome (My Opinion)
Pro - Wide variety of leaderboars Just about everthing you do from eating a human to getting a 10x hit combo there is a leaderboard for it. (which also makes the game even more addictive)

Con - As it is still in beta I seem to disconnect frequently this is very annoying while in dungeons or fighting big bosses.
Con - Sometimes can get frustrating a little bit of repatision in the game story play.

Altogether - Well Alltoghether this game in my opinion is fantastic I can a sure all people reading this I will be a long term player. If you like RPGS or Hack and slash Brutal games give this game a try. Even if you end up not liking it it's free not like your gonna have to pay any money. Also If you download and fall in love with the game its a game for live you didn't have to spend a penny on. Guys if I where you I would pick this game up and give it a go for an hour or so.

If not you might regret it. Hope this review thingy Helps And I hope to see you out on the battlefields Fellow warriors Stay sexy!.


Cheers :)

reviewText:
I wish there was a middle vote between a thumbs up and thumbs down.
Overall the game is decent, granted I only have 4.2 hours on the game.
But its just not enough for me to want to play it anymore.
Maybe I didn't give it enough time, maybe I did... I don't know.

Will I recommend this game? Yes
Why? It's free why not. Free is always good!

Gameplay and control is pretty decent (Remembering what keys do what can rack the brain). After 4 hours of play time I got pretty decent at combos.
Some troll type monsters can be challenging, just have to figure out a pattern on them. Run in, combo, block, block, run away and eat the little people if you get smacked around lol.

Give it a try its free and nothing to lose. For me at this moment in time I have other games that interest me more.
I may or may not come back to this game in the future.

reviewText: Unlike other reviews have said, this game is not a pay to win at all. First thing, is that the game is a very challenging game and you should not play it if you think its gonna be flippin World of Warcraft. This game has very odd mechanics that make me sooooooooo mad. This game is not a pay to win, but their are many mini transactions. One of the main mechanics in the game is that you can send enemies to someone else in your same area but in a different dimension (Void, Light, Chaos all have their own dimension).These enemies are so difficult, especcialy when there are those people who grind for days or pay real money to send boss-like creatures at you, that makes me infuriated when I'm at a lower level. Apart from that one thing, the monsters themselves are difficult as crap. There was a section I had to pass that had maybe 10 creatures? Yeah I though 10 was a meabsly number, I walk out there and get killed almost instantly :(. The point is that this game has some wonky mechanics but very fun ones at the same time. The thing that makes me infuriated the most is how fast your armor breaks... I'm just gonna stop before I get into that.

reviewText:
Such an interesting game concept, but it fails for lack fo scope. First, Ascend is a 3D beat'em up with special powers. The powers are fairly weak (even after I spent most of the free souls you get with a new account upgrading the first power, it just didn't do much damage or provide more than a couple seconds of stun), so I don't know why they even bother having them. They have cooldowns and are very expensive to upgrade, so it stands to reason that they would be powerful, but this just isn't the case. . .  and that's a shame because the ONLY thing that is different in character progression between you and any other character is which one of 3 gods you choose to follow. This choice will follow you through the game as it determines which special powers your character gets. Other than that, you get different combos based on the type of weapon you use. . .  and that's it.

Plus, while there are a handful of character customization options, you won't actually see them because your character wears different armor. There is no body-scaling or choices between different types of Caos warriors, so you'll always play as a hulking steroid-monkey in thick battle armor. It would be great if there was more variety. . .  maybe your Caos is a beautiful female archer or a cute but-lightning-quick rogue kid who is all about dodging and setting up vicious surprise attacks.

Basically, the ideas of Ascend are great, but they just didn't put enough into it to make it great. This shows in their pay-model too. Instead of having the ability to buy more gameplay options like mounts, different character classes, etc. the player can basically buy the in-game currency for power-ups (souls). This means the game is literally pay-2-win. While I personally don't have a problem with that in MMOs that focus on PvE, I do have a problem with it in MMOs that have elements of PvP.

reviewText:
I remembered playing this game for hours on end on the Xbox 360, so I thought it was great to see it moving over to PC as well. Can I reccomend this game to others? Certainly! Although, not everyone would enjoy it fully.

The game itself puts you in control of a being known as a Caos. Upon choosing from one of three gods (the gods represent the Dark, Void, and Light), you are sent out into the human world to bring down the reign of a massive creature known as the Titan, a former god who constantly devours humans and souls to stay alive. By capturing areas of the map through the raising of shrines and desecating of village altar, you bring your god's will and control to the area, driving the Titan further and further away from the main parts of the map.

The combat is similar to God of War, where timing your actions is important to winning an encounter, whether it be with the weak yet numerous troll warriors, or the massive hulking ogres that protect certain sites for the Titan. There's no jumping, and there are not any ways to speed up your progress through a level other than to have decent gear.

Speaking of gear: The armor and weapons in this game can be obtained in one of two ways. You can either find them while exploring the world and opening the chests they often hide in, or by purchasing them from the shop with souls recieved from the slying of enemies and also from chests. Souls CAN be bought with real-world money, which often puts certain players at a greater advantage, but the pay-to-win structure is VERY minimal, as you can find similar or better pieces of arms and armor out in the world. You can also use souls to upgrade your gear, as well as spells you obtain as you go. Depending on how you spend your souls, you can create a decent character WITHOUT the need to break out your credit card, something I've not done so far witht his game.

So, what is there to like about this game?

There's plenty to like. The surroundings change depending on which god controls which area, so a reather drab troll-held region will be far different from that of a void-held region, so it often gives a change in scenery (if you like that sort of thing). The villages are almost fully destructable, and the villagers and their warriors can be thrown, eaten, smashed, thrown off of your body...Yeah, these little guys have saved my skin on multiple occasions.

Combat is pretty straight forward in most cases, but the minibosses often require finesse and strategy to defeat. Bosses also test you,your character, and, on many occasions, your patience. Some are pretty powerful, even for a Caos with great gear.

Some things I didn't particularly like are the camera controls and the way some encounters play out. Because I played this game first on the 360, I am used to a controller (something this game, thankfully, supports). And, correct me if I'm wrong, but the camera controls on this port are a bit more touchy and wonky in some places. Encounters can also be rather repetitive and a little overwhelming as the number of enemies can double in an encounter if you accidentaly  fight close to another group of enemies.

While that's all I can personally complain about, the PvP also deserves (grudgingly) my respect. Instead of attacking another player directly, you have to use Crusade Spells to either curse or, if you're feeling generous, bless another player. You can send enemies from your world to another, create enhanced versions of the same creatures in their world, even give them boosts and protections. It depends on your personal taste.

Finally, the main component of the game, Ascension. After you reach level five and clear Crimhold Summit (the tutorial area, basically), you can send the current form of your Caos to be Ascended, and to fight on your behalf in the Crusade. Whatever gear you Ascend with is what that version of you will use, and will be taken from you. UNLESS you make them into Legacy items, which you can spend souls on to make them available to all of the Caos you create later on down the road. It's a nifty feature, but spending souls to unloack Legacy slots in the Ascending area can be troublesome.

Once you've Ascended, you'll be given the opportunity to re-equip and rename your next Caos, and also choose to serve a new God. In the 360 version, I served the Light exclusively. This port? The Void. Because those spells are pretty flashy.

But this is my opinion. If you choose to download this game, go right ahead! It's free to play, so you won't be losing any money on it (unless you buy souls), and it's a game you can jump into for almost any length of time.

So, if you download it, I'll see you out there, whether it be on the same side, or on the other end of a raided village.
